3o32PGfrVEeKdy1UTbPS3Q.text: Well,  the staff is extremely rude. The waitor took 20 minutes to get me my drink which was water, and she gave me soda. I waited an hour and a half for my food which they gave me the wrong one. And when I complained I get called the n word.

e0UhZit1-BhWiV3RdmmJ0w.text: Great restaurant. The staff are attentive, polite and extremely well informed about the food and wine, which are also wonderful. The restaurant itself is attractive, dark wood and there is a bar downstairs. Convenient if you are with a large group.The food is simple, rustic and delicious. Price wise, extremely good value for money.

o59v43hdhyDdfAulzBilSA.text: Goodness this place is phenomenal!Our party of 3 had a dinner of:- Cockles, leeks, and bacon- Duck confit salad- Sardines- Roast Middlewhite with a chestnut stuffing and red cabbage- Whole grilled mackerel with beets in a horseradish cream sauce- Partridge, snails, and garlic casserole- "Greens"- Bottle of Rioja (Grand Reserve)- White chocolate mousse- Chocolate malt ice cream- Pistachio brittle ice creamEverything was delicious, and I mean, everything. Standouts for me were: the broth that the cockles came in was delicious; the sardines were perfectly balanced with the citrus (grapefruit and orange slices); the Middlewhite had so much flavour; the mackerel was cooked to perfection; and the pistachio brittle was amazing. Service was a bit spotty but still attentive and I love the ambiance. As my coworker said after our meal, I was "blissed out on good food". I honestly will be talking about this meal at least for months and can't wait to return when I'm back in town next time.

gSwqfzGOKa5I7tMEWezqlA.text: After browsing the reviews on Yelp we decided to give Great  Queen Street a try. Since we didn't have a reservation we showed up right at 6 PM and we were kindly given a table until 8:15 PM. We were not disappointed. We ordered the duck crown for two which was to die for. The duck was done to perfection. We would definitely recommend this restaurant for its simplicity, sophistication and seasonal ingredients.

3g6BoJv1zti-jKSaqgLWtQ.text: Great. Loved it. Friend lives round the corner - it's his current local favourite. It was Saturday night - it was full, so we sat at the bar. Staff were amazingly friendly & helpful. Two of them advised on wine - we got a couple of samples before we bought. Ended up with a nice bottle of Rioja I had a nice samphire salad to start - friend had sardines, which were delicious. Then we shared a chicken pie. Holy smoke. Best chicken pie ever. Perfect pastry, magic sauce, outrageously tasty chicken.flickr.com/photos/rupert…  Too full for dessert. Sat and chatted and then wandered through the Saturday night West End madness for a while before heading home. Great evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

La-M-FVajFflxLJrXXbkkA.text: My husband found Great Queen Street on Yelp when we first moved to London a few months ago.  Turned out it was just around the corner from our flat.  Lucky us!   It is now our go-to restaurant.  We've been three times so far and have been consistently wowed by the food, service, and ambiance.  The menu seems to change daily and with homemade gingerbeer and delicious dishes.  I wish we could eat here every night.  Lots of great British meat dishes--pork and cockles in a stew, duck several ways.  I am learning to just order the special and enjoy, or ask the knowledgeable waiter what he would order that night.  One of the waiters said he had been eating at GQS for seven years and finally joined the staff as a waiter 6 months ago.Hope to return soon!

DK_lIhNeGVzJSFx1bxhZ8Q.text: After walking around for the London Open House event, I settled in for a late lunch at the place that just won British Restaurant of the Year in the London Restaurant Awards. It's been on my list for a while, and because they typically take bookings, and I know that its sister gastropub, the Anchor and Hope is hopelessly busy I was fortunate it was fairly quiet for that time of day. From the outside, it looks like an ordinary restaurant or pub, with only a picture of a crown amidst a dinner setting instead of name distinguishing it from its neighbours. Dozens of tables inside huddle near the front of the restaurant, with only three or four alfresco tables outside. Even though they had plenty of tables to choose from, I decided to sit at the bar, if anything, just to get a better perspective of the entire place, and for an easy sideways glance into the kitchen, full of flames and a relentless stream of orders in and out. Service wise, this place impressed me because not only was it fast, efficient but it was also friendly. Whilst perusing the interesting, apparently ever changing menu, they immediately placed a board topped with hearty bread chunks, butter, salt and coarse pepper, in front of me as well as a jug of chilled tap water and a small glass. I love this about places where you don't even have to ask for it. Despite the great service, what really matters to me is the quality of the food and I cannot express how delicious my meal ended up. With lots of tempting daily specials and many dishes resembling those you'd see at St Johns, I eventually settled for the seven hour lamb shoulder, and based on a recommendation, a side of green to go with it. At the same time, as I contemplated a red wine to go with, the bartender graciously offered me a sampling of their wines including their Beaujolais wine, a lighter red wine whose full flavour peaks when it's chilled. Although I settled for something different, I thought it very nice of them to offer. Being a seven hour lamb shoulder, it unsurprisingly came out quickly since it didn't really need any other cooking. Even at £13, I thought the entire bowl was going to defeat my normally fearsome appetite, only to be satiated by the soft, melt in your mouth flesh accompanied by sweet carrots, and other vegetables in the dark gravy. The bright green cabbage brought a sharp and fresh contrast to the almost overpoweringly rich flavours of the lamb, and let's just say I walked out of there a very content person. Great for groups, couples and individuals, Great Queen Street offers something for everyone. If only I had room for dessert, I'm sure it would have been just as amazing as the main dish.

Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

TBRtFSrMvyedZSOgs_ZwUQ.text: While Great Queen Street may lack originality in name, I can assure you that argument can not be made about the food, atmosphere, and wait staff.  Seasonal food (aka Slow food) is their focus, menu appears to be constantly updated and always offering a type of "feature beer" of the day/week/etc.  My wife had the Fennel Pomegranate Salad and I went with Shepherds Pie.  We also ordered a side of non-descriptly titled "Greens".  We sampled on all three, which were amazingly robust and flavorful.  The Fennel was cooked perfectly, not too soft nor hard and the pomegranate burst through with flavor over the "anise-like" quality of the fennel.  The greens were actually brussel sprout tops in a butter bath/sauce.  Their coloring was so bright that you could have created a new color in your crayon box.  Flavor yet again was killer.  Shepherds pie was also right-on.  Couldn't have been happier with our three choices.  The restaurant is is dressed down, very informal feeling.  The staff do a great job focusing their attention on your service.Will consider a return to this spot if ever in a fix to make a decision on food.

4L9szjHQVHw7_mW36OMFdg.text: Funny how the penultimate day I am in London I find the best place for British food.  I know that I gave the Troubador in Ear's Court a high rating, but it wasn't full British per se.I went to the handy dandy Yelp to help me find a good place to eat that I hadn't been to yet.  Great Queen St. came up highly rated and with real English food.It's an unassuming place packed with people enjoying food.  We ended up at the bar so we didn't have to wait.  Their beer selection was limited but they had a nice local lager.  The menu was simple and had interesting points to it.  Everything seemed to fit the season also which was great to see.  I asked for the most British thing on the menu and the server said it had to be the faggot.  After chuckling, I order the faggot with a side of potatoes and my buddy got the quayle.The dish was delectable.  The faggot was flavorful and wasn't overpowered by the suace which I thought it would be after tasting the sauce.  The filling was an interesting combination of meats which came together perfectly.I ended up getting a dessert as it was my last night with a great meal and how could I not try a British dessert.  I got a chocolate pie.  WOW!!  it was very tasty but not too sweet and had other flavors in there besides chocolate.When I go back to London, I will come here for some more good British food.

bXg8yBKlIiIlwp29z2fD6g.text: This place had great food and great customer service! I was trying to find a place that could accommodate my dietary restrictions and they were very nice about it! I had the partridge, the split pea soup, the syllabub, the mackerel (not all on the same day!) all hearty but I didn't feel there was a dead weight in my stomach throughout the day. Great location, on a slightly less busy street, and attentive staff that always made sure that I was happy. I love the fact that both their lemonade and ginger beer were not sweet at all, and it was more like a digestif. Definitely good for an unsettled stomach!

pIyX64KgROGZDNhP5hTYXA.text: The menu changes all the time, and I was here a while ago so I can barely recall what I ate. Some sort of tangy squid dish, rabbit with chorizo and who knows what else. But I can tell you that it was all super delicious! Just go. Pick something at random. You're welcome.

v3A-NYalv_mlX-UXls0OBg.text: I spent most of this afternoon burping up bunnie. Yep if there was any vegetarian left in me it has now completely dissolved in a peter rabbit pie with a suet pastry. I will admit not that I showed my meat eating inexperience by claiming that suet was potato based but hey, give the girl some slack.From the moment I walked into this place I felt happy. For started we were placed by the window with a perfect people watching position and secondly I later found out that this is the sister venue to The Hope and Anchor - the amazing pub that dazzled me with fish dishes that I have still yet to eat in! The menu here though is impressive, all of it seasonal and created daily. You are welcomed by positively the most intelligent servers I have ever met in London. They really know the food can explain everything on the menu and relish in that slightly without arrogance. Also with some freshly baked sour dough bread and butter...mmmm....butter!The food itself is wonderfully British and if you don't like traditional food, featuring a lot of meat then this place is not for you. But it's simple, perfectly prepared and a fantastic enjoyable meal.

7I4Hoct1X3XITvKxwG16RA.text: I was toying between a 4 and a 5, but I'm going to be generous as I had a truly wonderful meal here a few weeks ago. Not for the vegetarians or for those who are somewhat wary to try game or traditional cuts of meats, but a must for those who want hearty fare - especially on a cold December evening!Went with OH and a couple of friends on their recommendation and it didn't disappoint. We started with a round of oysters - delish! I then had partridge - never had it before and it was lush (thought it might have been a little gamier though but will remember that for future reference) OH had ox casserole (not oxtail - just ox) one friend had belly pork, and the other decided upon smoked haddock. We ordered a couple of sides of potatoes and some greens. Was definitely worth ordering more potatoes - they were also very yummy!We were all pretty stuffed after the meal and so we savoured the remainder of our (very affordable and tasty) wine with a couple of cheese platters - thoroughly reccommend, truly scrumptious!One other nice touch about the menu was that several dishes were to share between 2 - in particular the sole and the pheasant pie (which i want to try next time if we are in season).Can't remember exactly  how much the bill came to - think it was around £130 or so, but that did include the wine which was probably around £30.Have since recommended it to loads of people and am looking forward to a return visit

q33QNcupu44osYA2qjFeoQ.text: Oooohhhh, nom nom nom nom.... rabbit pie.     Yes, really. Upon first bite I turned from a human Laura into cartoon Laura and instantly knew what Elmer Fudd was rambling on about for all those years: Wabbits weally are wather guuud! Especially when encased in perfect savory crust that involves suet. (Yup -- that's the fat that grows around the kidneys in cows and sheep, and it's guuuud too.)The menu was practically in another language with all of the eloquent foodie terms that end up meaning things like "fat" or "innards," but with a server/chef/angel that took the time to delicately explain each dish in drool-worthy detail, it was like our own table translator.This is the little sister to Anchor and Hope, another top British foodie destination of which I will soon be visiting after this flawless experience. This is certainly British food at its best and I challenge anyone to question the competency of English cuisine after a meal at Great Queen Street.

qZPE6h0TuDj3lf62qzKTMg.text: They offer the best national food in London. The products are always fresh and perfectly cooked. You have to book a table before you go there, because it is almost always overcrowded.

ZvKpSMqgDzsh1dNPoW0x9w.text: I found this place on Qype while searching for a place to have dinner with my husband. We were seated almost immediately even though we showed up without a reservation. Really lovely decor and staff. The menu was interesting, slightly wacky, sometimes difficult to choose from. I would recommend it to all my friends.

q_otjYvP2TM1PTBYlaO-Cw.text: Have been back here many times.  On the latest visit I got to order something I've been eyeing up for some time - the 7 hour slow cooked lamb.  This easily feeds 5 and costs £64, comes with dauphinois potatoes and veg.  A minty pea starter recommended by the waiter was a great complement to the lamb which arrived shortly after.  Soooo good. Do not miss GQS!

8Q2hiI6NKCD0nuaF0oA6ZQ.text: A local haunt for me, this is also one of London's busiest gastropubs. The younger and more easily to get to sister of Southwark's Anchor & Hope, Great Queen Street serves quite tasty traditional pub food that is more posh and innovative than your average g-pub in town. The meats and particular cuts used here can be a bit wild (their game dishes are superb, however). The menu changes daily and is very seasonal so you know you're getting the best of British produce. My favorite dish I've had is the Arbroath Smokie (a delicate white fish they serve filleted open in a delicious cream sauce). The staff is very helpful with any questions you may have on some of the less common menu items or any of their wines, but trust their opinions! I have yet to be steered wrong by them and have been coming here for over a year now.Definitely make reservations before coming if you don't want to sit at the counter.

vdFxJQixGW8gp2Yq5DCBVw.text: I was invited to meet at Great Queen Street by some "Foodie" friends of mine from the states who make sure to dine here every time they make it to London. And I could see why it would be a favorite for foodies. The fare was definitely a step above average Pub grub, with entrees such as pigs cheek and sardines. I do enjoy food, but I guess I am not that adventurous in my selections enough to be considered a foodie as I only ordered a beef burger on dripping toast. When it was delivered it looked delicious, and the taste and texture was average. Even though nothing on the plate looked "dangerous" I spent the rest of the day in and out of the bathroom. I don't want to speak poorly of this place seeing as how the wait staff was very friendly and my host's seemed to enjoy their meal, but personally I didn't think that Great Queen street was that great... queen.. street.

rgm5GzQggdydRUCW5x9_1w.text: Wonderful meal with friends after a jaunt to the Bond in Motion exhibit at the London Film Museum.Classic yet innovative menu of shear yumminess. The steak and ale pie for 2 was epic, my kidneys with bacon/lentils were heaven, the pork chop was sublime. We didn't have the whole roast pork shoulder but it looked incredible.Solid bar menu also, good cocktails, good beer and wine.Great Service.Good idea to book ahead.

IjC6PdLu_7adp2WxiVESrg.text: Nice. This Yank left pleased. First off, the friendly service. You made a solo, foreign diner feel welcome. Second off, the food. Nice, though I still can't fathom London prices. My salad was delicious. My cold Devon crab was nice too, but way too much work. And the mayonnaise seemed to be from a jar. Finally, the service. Superb. Thank you. Go.

m23uwMyrVD1phLFeHufheQ.text: What a great gastropub! We made a last minute call for a dinner reservation and by how easily we got the booking,we were thinking...maybe they aren't busy Saturday night? Boy were we wrong. It was bustling around 9pm and we had to wait a bit for our table. Everyone working there was incredibly friendly and service was pretty fast.We went with a couple of their specials. An ox stew with gnocchi as our main and some asparagus and salami on the side. The stew was amazing. Rich and comforting with puffy gnocchi pillows in a tomato base. Yummlicious! We definitely will come back again to try some of their other items

Set-SijQafZBlOdpB_qYpQ.text: A true gem in London's Covent Garden area. Had the "rare chicken pie" for two which was mind-blowing amazing (and they ran out of by dessert so we were not alone). Also had the "onion soup with stinking bishop" appetizer which was an excellent British interpretation of a French staple.A couple of small service hiccups is all that kept this from five stars. If you are looking at this place, stop thinking about it and give it a go -- you won't be sorry!

ZiFxdEv94OMCttI8tbHVwA.text: Awesome food and really helpful staff in a superb location... only downside is the price for beers... £6 per bottle is a little too steep, even for a good beer.Well worth a visit.

FP19BaDYyYh9bvd9ntxGPQ.text: Service was with a wonderful smile. Menu somewhat arty farty and I don't eat fish so my choices limited but thats my issue not theirs.  Quality of food excellent and taste devine. For me its slightly overpriced and a 200ml Diet Coke was over £2.40... Thats NOT good, but plenty of tap water on offer by the staff.The bill just came with 12.5% service included which I asked to be removed. Less than 2 minutes later before I was able to pull out some coins and put my card away, the (?) manager approached and asked if the service was OK because I didn't pay it... Well I find that damn cheeky... Poor tourists who dont notice that added and dont know its optional by law! I have now down graded to 3 Stars because of this issue and the ordasity of being approached.  Again I tell you why I have been negative so you can draw your own opinion.  I WONT however be returning here... My money will spend anywhere!

Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Delicious! Lamb balls in tomato... Mmmmmm

0yk1qaJKO9uQv4WRyBIMYA.text: As a party of one, this place was solid but nothing amazing.  I came here because I saw pictures of amazing pies and other specialties but the interesting items available on the menu (like chicken pie and beef wellington) were for 2-3 people, so I was fairly disappointed.  I ordered the lemon sole with a butter sauce, and it was tasty, but nothing particularly special. The menu changes frequently so maybe I just didn't order the right thing, but I wasn't very impressed, and I wouldn't necessarily recommend it.

ZF7J1b-wCFQ9O9qD45ub3Q.text: My husband and I were visiting London from NYC.  What a great find thanks to Yelp.  We shared beets salad, smoked rainbow trout.  Which were both very good but I definitely adored the trout.  Entree we shared the steak & ale pie with a big piece of bone with marrow!!!  Not that I'm a pie expert but wow, crust was amazing, and the meat was so flavorful and not a bit over cooked.  We also had fresh veggie and hand cut chips.  So fresh!  Dessert was buttermilk pudding (like panna cotta) with prunes.  Service was impeccable.  I highly highly recommend!

XaVjMLT7hC9x6Is9CqngMw.text: Absolutely loved this place. Wanted to try something different with my husband while we were in London. I got the pigs cheeks and my husband got the rabbit. They were both amazing!!! We had the apple tart for dessert which was also amazing. We sat at the bar because it was a little less noisy and had great service from both ladies at the bar. Couldn't have been more pleased. It is a bit loud in there though because it's so small, and I would also recommend a reservation. But over all, wonderful and different food at a reasonable price with great service. If I ever find myself back in London I would definitely visit this restaurant again!

KgcHNQxETREl7dWWyvrLZg.text: Quite nice.  They take old school "British" cuisine and give it a sleek update with some mediterranean flavor.  Casual and friendly atmosphere and, despite the neighborhood, not overpriced.  I think they could do a better job on the wine list --- given the many game-like options, more in the Burgundy style would be preferable.  I had- Grilled squid and hot peppers (guindillas).  A rather spartan dish, but cooked nicely and tasty.- Whole roasted partridge, celeriac mash, and greens.  The bird was beautifully prepared, with nice crispy skin and a medium/medium-rare interior.  Luckily I had recently had lots of practice carving fowl, so getting the meat off this little bird's bones wasn't too much of a struggle.- Quince and almond tart. A nice, crumbly tart.Others at the table had a foie gras terrine, the saddle of rabbit shared plate, grilled lamb hearts, and the whole plaice.  All looked quite good.  The other desserts that people had were okay--nothing stellar.  It's not the most inventive but everything seems to be executed with a high degree of precision.

7NPwYD7G9POCsDtyN_vmFw.text: We came for lunch on a weekday after reading reviews online about this place. We weren't that hungry so we ordered the pork and duck terrine, small meat and cheese plate with quince paste, and the braised beef, ceps, oregano and polenta for entree. The pork and duck terrine was pretty good, but wasn't the best terrine we've had. The braised beef and the polenta was probably the best thing we ordered. It was tasty and well done. Service was good and our waitress answered any questions we had, but they weren't as attentive as I thought they would be. Based on other reviews, it seems like it might be better to go for dinner instead.

P-qjzr_VcuxJ1Z-uLTaflQ.text: Food was very good.  Service was fantastic.  Waiter know the wine list and and great recommenations.

KGgOVWyosAop3uZTjVSjmg.text: My husband found Great Queen Street listed in the Lonely Planet guidebook while we were searching for a spot to have dinner on the final night of our week in London, and it ended up being one of my favorite meals of the trip. As we walked in we were warmly greeted and warned that there was only one Chicken Pot Pie (meant for 2 to share) left in the kitchen. Thank goodness we quickly claimed it! The pie was SO delicious, fresh and flavorful--the perfect meal for our final night in London.

0pnqajrrkv6O62G4-66lQQ.text: Had the best rabbit pie of my life. Also the menu changes daily which gives a lot of variety. You never know what to expect when you dine at great queen street. The duck confit salad was by far the best salad and duck I ever had. The duck was tender and flavorful and combined with the salad just right.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. BEST duck confit salad.

gjWx0iOPmNqQPqXXwkdDyw.text: Overall Meh Minus. Food was OK.  The mushrooms on toast were nice and the fried cheese stuffed courgette flower was a bit grainy.  For mains, the kid of goat was under seasoned and gnarly. The chickpeas were hard. The quail was fine but the accompanying grilled onions were awesome. Dessert was meringue and custard for two.  Pretty good. The tables that got the leg of lamb for 3 had better food than we did.  Service was downright terrible. Absent and uninterested.  The manager should be sacked. Teams with bad attitudes are signs of poor managers.  My hotel concierge told me they stopped recommending here (Go to Beast!) and I did not listen. Next time I will.

e4ykZkwoUYMQbe92cWOOig.text: Amazing, perfect food. Pleasant, low-key dining area. Good service. Um, perfect?Well, it is hard to find and not really labelled from the outside. We even asked a hotel valet across the street while we were wandering around, and he'd never heard of it. Also, you must have a reservation, they're just too popular. And it may be hard to find room for dessert!Once we did find the place, my friend and I both ordered the caramelized onion and cheese tart. So much flavor packed into this dish, and it was much bigger than you'd normally expect for London portions. We were really happy with it as a pre-theatre meal and would totally go back.

xC8DG43xYdXj50chHHpmXQ.text: One of the best gastropubs I've ever been too. The Prawn risotto melts in your mouth.

81oRsXZG5mvKlbdrXfV_kA.text: My husband and I found this place on yelp when we were in London last month. We ordered the Beef pie for 2 and it was AMAZING! The best thing we ate in London. It was a little pricey but worth it. We ate the entire thing. Service was also great. Highly recommended.

FJMQCXJKnnFnPUeH8zN2Lg.text: Went there twice while I was in London for a week. Interesting food. Just wish they'd served the whole partridge, not chopped.

CGwCigZEU2XBEGwuaib_uw.text: I been here once in 2010. It was good for Sunday lunch with the lamb shoulder for 4 people. I remember it was a lot of food. Fast forward to 2014, does this place still have what it takes? We arrived with a reservation for 10 people but two extra people came along. They were happy to move tables around to accommodate.  Looking at the menu on a Saturday night I saw the lamb shoulder, ooooh who's gonna get in on this feast tonight? We made a group decision to order a main each and share the lamb. WOW between the group we barely finished all of the lamb because there was so much of it. It was delicious and very moorish especially with the dauphinoise potatoes as a side.I had the onglet steak. It was cooked rare and well cooked. Only downside was that they cut it up for me. I am not a huge fan of that because I like to cut my own meat. Otherwise a flawless meal with great service.There is a cool cocktail bar downstairs too but didn't have a chance to check it out

FPBInntQg6cBMNMTqC7kdA.text: Did not meet high expectations. This place was alright, but I somehow expected more. The food was middle of the road and instantly forgettable. Service was a bit slow when the room was fully packed. Expensive for what it is.

CwvU0Ia_qKuiUu5DqDB41A.text: The food here is pricey but extremely well done, I had the quail and it was very good. The restaurant quickly filled up for lunch which is always a good sign.

YyqPvKZ3WSB9U5ogkNURBQ.text: Back to the beginning of November 2015 when I was looking for restaurants to go to for our trip to London, I found this place and figured "why not". The reviews are very good and there's quite a lot of them too so I shouldn't be badly surprised when actually going there.In the end, I have to say that personnally, I really enjoyed the place. The food was good, the waiters were friendly (though the one we had seemed a bit stressed somehow, even though there was basically almost nobody left to wait on) and I also liked how the place looked. Also, I have to say that I loved the food. Apart from the dessert which was some regular ice cream that I had chosen and that was all in all just ice cream, I found the other dishes I had to taste quite good and to also look fairly nice too, which is always a nice touch.Now, everything about our visit there didn't make me so happy. I was honestly a bit surprised with the way they presented their menu, on a single sheet of paper with basically no structure at all and just text. That wasn't really something that reassured me. Something else I found odd - but I have to guess it depends on the person and their taste - was how they used those little glasses for every single drink. Be it water or alcohol, the same kind of glass was used. That's not something negative, by all means, but I did find it odd.And finally, more than anything else, I was surprised by the price we paid for two. Keep in mind that we both had an alcoholic drink, a starter, a main dish and a dessert. All in all, we had to pay £97 with the service included. Honestly, I found that to be very expensive. Maybe that's normal by London's standards with restaurants, but considering it was my first time there, I had some trouble swallowing the pill, even though I had swallowed the food itself without any problems a few minutes earlier.

yVR7DEBP9ZLub9_fyDkQLw.text: Very full place on a week night. Cute little gastropub with a changing menu. Friendly helpful service.The prosecco with strawberry was a refreshing start and the squash fritters light, crispy and flavourful. The hake was absolutely delicious.I also had a taste of the almond prune tart which was good, not too sweet.

-CgMNJbF86-e8UmvHAW4sQ.text: Excellent pre theatre experience here - we had no reservation and were seated quickly and assigned a v young, attentive and toothy server. Waters were brought and shortly after our buffalo mozzarella and tomato salad and calf liver plates. My husband had the beer on tap which was described as slightly warm flat and bitter which we found hilarious but were offered a taste. He found it to be none of those things and enjoyed a full pint. My salad was a modest portion but done v well - the mozz was sprinkled in a crunchy topping and added some textural interest to the creaminess. His calf liver was truly unctuous and well sauced. We topped off w the chocolate fritters which we noticed many other tables enjoying. My husband actually closed his eyes while biting in as the first one released the heat of the freshly made treat. It was akin to a soufflé in that way and we were so happy there were two so we didn't have to share! Pricing is decent and the overall ambiance is happy and satisfied. Will consider this a go-to whenever we are in the neighbourhood for a show.

BHJC6aCboOmTQ8_DAhNsGA.text: As good as it gets. Food, service, vibe and value are all spot on for me. Delicious modern british food with great ingredients. The standout for me was the rabbit pie- I could have eaten the whole thing.Bring some friends, try lots of dishes (open your mind palette to some new animal parts), share it all, and you'll have a good meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Rice semi frido
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Lamb neck
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Plaice.

nmWGu8uqnon5zk6t-7_Kvg.text: Five stars for the food! My boyfriend and I shared crab on toast to start and then went for the lamb fillet and the pot roast partridge, swapping plates halfway... I love doing this as I get to sample more of a restaurant's food :)I was initially a bit concerned as the two-person tables are a bit crammed in and placed in rows - the waiters have to regularly  squeeze past you. As well as this, the restaurant doesn't play any music upstairs and so there is quite a din when this place gets busy. However, these two things do make the restaurant a bit more cosy and intimate!Staff are really knowledgeable and friendly, and were happy for us to take our time to decide. My boyfriend had a Freedom beer (he testifies this was really nice) and  I had a carafe of white wine which they then serve in teeny tiny glasses. I can't decide if his made me drink faster or slower!The food was too quality and I will definitely return; even though it's pricier than a lot of nearby restaurants, it's worth it.Afterwards, we went downstairs to their cellar bar which had really bright lighting and so wasn't as atmospheric as it could have been. I had a Moscow mule which was lovely, but my bf's silver bullet was hard to finish... A tad too strong! I'd avoid it if you don't want to get hammered :)

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Pot roast partridge and apple black pudding
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Lamb fillet, split peas and chermoula
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Crab on toast

7lNyJ0TJb-6cGGRB5R5e6g.text: JUST GO HERE AND EAT ALL THE THINGS.which, funnily enough, are on the menu :) service brilliant, as is the food. stop reading and start eating.

DPJsdVzoNqEIrVGnNnHR9A.text: I hosted a dinner party for 12 people at this restaurant and everything went perfectly. The service was excellent from making the reservations to food service to completing the bill - all excellent. The food was outstanding. Lots of delicious options with outstanding flavors and textures. The wine that was paired with the meal was excellent as well.The crowning moment was the satisfaction from all my guests. It was a business dinner at a restaurant I had never been to, so I was nervous, but everyone was so happy in the end. I really look forward to returning to Great Queen Street.

vsTp1foXtUNDOtMEFRG7wQ.text: My first night in London is off to a great food start!Upon reading the reviews here, I decided this was a good first place to start.  I showed up close to 9:00pm I believe, the place was busy and nearly packed.  They managed to find me a small table inside just a few minutes which was nice.As others have mentioned, the bread actually came out before my water (though only by a minute or so), but that was literally the case.  The service was good, the staff was helpful and timely, no complaints there.The main dish I had was an Ox heart, served with some spinach greens and chips on the side.  I'd gone in thinking I'd get rabbit, but this was just too good to pass up as it was a special.  I don't remember the wine it was paired with, but that it was very good and matched nicely (a red).  It was prepared perfectly, had lots of flavor, and was an excellent portion size (filling but not stuffing).  The chips were also great, crisp on the outside but not overdone, warm and cooked right on the inside.After the main course I had a dessert of jelly and biscotti of which both were great and spreading the jelly on the biscotti was very tasty, and finally some Earl Grey tea.All of this was for £30, which I think is a great value.  I can see returning on a subsequent trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Ox heart (special).

Rutc2GbZHVCQ29Qe_r1VbQ.text: The place itself is very nice, wooden and more traditional. The food is British and unfortunately doesn't have the greatest choice for vegetarians BUT I must say the beans on toast were unexpectedly good! The waitress was very friendly and the wine good! For a relaxed dinner this place is def good.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

r3lHb58zEIzBhrM7LXD8Yg.text: What a wonderful place to have dinner! Made a quick reservation online through Open Table and was able to snag a table. Warmly greeted as I waited for my friend, and the staff didn't give me the stink eye as my friend ran late about 15 minutes behind. Fantastic food--a bit comfort food like with braised and roasted meats. The menu changes frequently. Flavorful, thoughtful, and delicious!

mZIzD32rwIsgbrHbKOdC9g.text: Last night in London and we wanted some traditional British fare. Yelp steered us to Great Queen St. and it wasn't wrong. Best meal of our trip. Tables were all reserved so we sat at the bar. Good beer, great atmosphere, and delicious food - partridge and cannelinis, baked st tola (goat cheese) with leeks and pumpkin, and fig and raspberry tart for dessert.The entire experience was perfect. A must-go if you're in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. fig and raspberry tart with hazelnut cream
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. baked st tola with creamy leeks and pumpkin

KZfPjszbC1Rqnsiz4m3LGg.text: First of all, I agree with past reviews in that the food was really good. We went for my birthday dinner around 8:30pm on a Monday night. It was still really packed however we were lucky enough to get the last table in the back. I ordered the chickpea dish, which had chickpeas, mashed potatoes and grilled vegetables. It was very flavorful and very filling (I could only finish half of it). The mushroom plate was heavier, with fried mushroom/cheese/breadcumb rolls and courgette. We loved the crusty whole wheat sourdough bread that came out before the meal as well!The reason I gave this restaurant 3 stars is primarily because of the service. Service was really slow, and it took forever to get our dishes and then finally get the check. Our server was nice, however nothing out of the ordinary. It was also really hot in the restaurant, but probably because of how many people were in there. Prices are slightly higher than our normal meals, but still reasonable.I would try it if I was in the area!

pxFWH0qrv-M4uBCL1KDBDw.text: My friend highly recommended this place because it was her favorite place when she lived here; hence, we walked so far to try this place out (we didn't rent a car in London).When we walked in around 6:00pm, 70% of the restaurants were already filled; there was one table available outside the restaurant, we asked for it, the server said OK as long as we give them our credit card to keep. We ordered their steamed whole fish, steaks, bottles of red wine, artichoke and desserts; the fish was amazingly fresh and tasty, we were impressed that they even serve whole fish (with the head); steaks were also perfectly cooked and melt in our mouth. The wine the server recommend was quite nice, smooth and goes so well with their steaks.Service was alright, perhpas they were quite busy so they were not too attentive. Overall, a very nice experience at this restaurant and I do recommend here for other people who visit this area.

xbxPDv1DwLQid7xWVbNLlw.text: This place was delicious.  We had the steak and ale pie and it was delicious but the most delicious dish we had was the cauliflower.  I must say that the cauliflower was one of the most delicious dishes.   Their beer selection is great as well. I recommend this place.  I am not in London often  but I must say I will come back here next time I am in town.

6MsfO4RqXwIuco-ihnQzPw.text: On a summery day my friend and I decided it would be the best of ideas to get out for a glass of wine. She, being a born and raised Londoner, is my most trusted map of the city. So willingly I let her drag me to whatever place she thought would be fabulous. Great Queen Street it was. The well hidden cellar bar is supposedly really crowded normally, but the rare appearance of the sun meant that nobody obviously wished to stay under the ground. We asked if we could have a drink outside instead and a friendly waitress guided us to a table. It's a treat as such to sit outdoors in London. I kinda wish there were more terraces for days like these. Sitting in the evening sun I ordered a glass of wine, while my friend opted for a glass of sherry.What I loved, other than the really friendly and patient waitress and the nice sunny terrace, is the fact that the restaurant has multiple really affordable wines on offer that can be ordered by the glass. To find an affordable drink in central London is a gift in itself, but to have the option to choose between multiple red wines that are all priced less than a fiver is unique. Other alcoholic beverages, including my friends sherry and a whole range of cocktails, are equally well-priced, so I will definitely return when I have the chance.

uzwkxzl1sgSnly4NGrzAWg.text: Reservation is highly recommended!Food was great. Very nice staff. Unfortunately they ran out of Beef Wellington but the lamb for 3 was cheaper and the portion was massive!I would definitely return.

_JucUqrntwVHwa2AvpIQGQ.text: Came here on a Friday night last week with my boyfriend. We walked in without reservations and sat at the bar and got drinks and appetizers. We were lucky that they were able to seat us! We didn't think we'd be able to get a table (which I really wanted) but the staff made that happen for us. Definitely a place you should make reservations for (I had no idea as it was my first time there). Cocktails here are great. You can get wine by the carafe (hurray!) and they have a cask ale that's also pretty good. We had the pigs head croquettes, eel salad, and the chicken pie for 2. For dessert we had the beignet with Victoria plums...which was mind blowingly good. The staff was really great too.

r8buBPnNH9eU27yUi8bWGQ.text: The nicest and most generous bartender I have ever met in London. Thanks Gareth. I hope I got it right.  I'll be back.The plum vodka was nice the whiskey was good.Can't wait to taste everything behind the bar.

L7bvSgZEoBYS4YfHOVyvHQ.text: My girlfriend and I decided that our last meal in London before traveling back to the States should be a "proper bit" of British food, and we took a chance on Great Queen Street. When we walked in the place wasn't full but we were told all the tables were booked (always a good sign) but they were happy to seat us at the bar which actually wasn't overrun with drinkers. The menu was pretty phenomenal with a lot of things US eaters might consider "game" meats like ox, rabbit, partridge and mutton--but I feel like they were all pretty accessible for someone wanting to try something out of the ordinary but still slightly familiar and not too far out of your comfort zone. I had the partridge with cannelloni beans and it was pretty darn spectacular. The broth/stock it was served with was great and flavorful. My girlfriend had a leek, pumpkin and goat cheese concoction that was equally good--so good well probably spend the weekend trying to replicate it. Luckily, partridges are pretty small so there was room for dessert. We had a fig and raspberry tart that may have been the best thing we ate of our whole vacation (and we had just come from Paris). Well likely try and recreate this as well!The service was great, friendly and well informed about the menu and ready to explain, the atmosphere was perfect, and the craft beer selection was great--it's nice to not have the corona/heinekin/budweiser safety net when overseas. And the price for all that (including a few pints) was just under £40. If I'm ever back in London, it's the first dinner I'm having. And maybe the second.

qWEWyDZ3xmW-dpc1ZSeQFg.text: British Country food. Friendly staff/owner. Menu changed dailyI found this place on Yelp while staying overnight in London. The premise is real English food - not the fish and chips rot you normally get, but more traditional fare. The restaurant was full (good sign on a Thursday night), but I was able to sit at one of the three tables outside. The menu changes daily based on what ingredients are available. I chose a venison with barley dish that was slow cooked to perfection. The service was a bit irregular, but not bad for the UK and the owner/manager? was very enthusiastic and helpful. When i talked to the business they didn't know they were on Yelp or what Yelp was!All in all, a good choice instead of the usual curry houses or other imported cuisines. P.S. I am so happy Yelp now is supporting London!

xFZEiYuU-Zk5k6OaDISR1g.text: I am NOT an adventurous eater.  I am also decidedly not a fan of British food.  I do not like fish, and meats that the British dig into without thinking about it are often just too gamey for my tastes.  When a friend suggested this place, she didn't realise I think just how picky I can be, but I decided to roll with it.  I'm REALLY glad I rolled with it.  This place was great!  Awesome atmosphere, and the wait staff really were as friendly and smart as everyone says.  Very patient people, never made us feel rushed despite making it clear when we booked ahead (and you MUST book ahead, this place is absolutely hoppin') that we WOULD need to clear out by 7:45 to make room for the next wave of people.  The food was fab.  We shared the goat with chicory, neither of which I have eaten in the past.  I admit, rare meat really weirds me sometimes.  But this was cooked so beauitfully in a lovely sauce, I really really enjoyed it.  The rarer pieces had to go to my comrade, and so I didn't feel like I entirely filled up, but the food was so beautiful and so nicely prepared and so DIFFERENT that I just really enjoyed myself. I liked that the decor was understated and pub like, but the food was first-class.  I do have to say that while my friend loved it downstairs as well, I found it creepy and clausterphobic.  For those who prepare a venue with windows, stick to the upstairs.  Very yummy, worth the cost, and worth trying something new.  Hooray!

U1mdnb4mGi6_9ba6fdgPiQ.text: We wandered in to Great Queen Street looking for something to eat on a Monday evening, and we were seated immediately but were told we would need to vacate our table in an hour and a half.  Suited us fine.Nice ambience, Rustic, floorboards, plain decor, admittedly it is a little squashed in.  One or two too many tables.The menu is interesting, slightly wacky, difficult to choose from in some cases. The most interesting dishes were sharing meals, and luckily I found someone happy to share a chicken pie for 2.  It was served in a generous iron dish, with a shortcrust lid, and was delicious.  It cost about £30.Don't bother with the homemade ginger beer.  It is £1.90 for a glass filled to the brim with ice, and a tiny amount of beer, which was not sweet enough.Service was very good, food was excellent.  I would return.

NIr1EVaz2mykDTrzOumjvg.text: Stepping into this establishment is like stepping into an old English country pub. When we came it was a busy night. We hoped to get a table but none were left. However they welcomed us at the bar where we enjoyed our meal. We had the sweet corn soup to start & shared their popular rabbit & mushroom pie. We also had a side of greens. We loved the soup & was perfect for a chilly night. For the most part, the pie was good... Just a little under seasoned. The rabbit was super tender & flavorful. However, I did not get the mushroom flavor. The side of greens was also a bit under seasoned. Service was friendly & attentive. I would definitely return & try the other entrees. I heard their roasted chicken is also very good.

-EB_S1jwc46Ydaw8LMTgBA.text: Best meal I had this year. Make reservations though. Friday I arrived to a less than full restaurant at 6:30 PM. I asked if I could book a table for three at 7:00 PM and I was told the earliest available would be at 9:45 PM. Thankfully the bar was completely open, but by 7:15 PM the whole place was packed. Tiny beer selection with only one on tap. Local, as in UK, thankfully. A huge wine list and only one cider. The menu has so many good dishes to choose from.  My mates ordered the rabbit for two and boy said it was so good. I ordered the slow braised pork with fennel and quince. Just wow! So, so good. It was melt in your mouth I need another bite now good. We decided to follow that up with the pear tart. That was so good and en we discovered the Today's Special board. We had the brown bread ice cream as well. Just more goodness. I highly recommend this restaurant. Great atmosphere, nice staff, reasonable prices, just wonderful.

8yu91MIvda3HHoiPUapdBg.text: One of the best restaurants I've been. The food was really good and not that expensive. We sat at the bar because we we're a bit late and all the tables were taken but it didn't matter. Next time when I'm in Londen I'm definitely going back.Enjoyed the atmosphere, food and staff. Five stars well deserved.

C4lI7BM-ogFbMtN89lIMlg.text: Michelin star worthy.  This place delivers on what British food should be.  Standout dish was the Romesco (moon broccoli???) salad, with sultanas, pine nuts, manchego, and some other tasty bits.  Both vegetarian dishes they had that evening were superb and well thought out.  They have a cozy bar downstairs to grab a reasonably priced cocktail before you get dinner.If I lived closer to this place, I'd be a regular!  Make sure to get reservations in advance, as it's tough to get a table the day of.

mMm0f0LM5ewdNrZJzVu63g.text: Lovely place. Randomly walked in on a Christmas season Saturday lunch. Sat down at the bar and were taken care of immediately.  Had pig's cheek and some smoky fsh. Perfect for the cold windy winter day, with the food being fresh, hot and juicy. Will come again when in the neighborhood.

lhFo91u13vE_UWbT1f-kVw.text: Had some luck on the Lottery, so we went to an ehibition and went here for some eats. Really, Really good. Very impressed, and yes, it cost a bit more than I normally payit was well worth it!! Lovely staff and we left well satiated. Will be going again..if I win again!

HjL_o9pI4VBb7IrwyETR1g.text: So, I did have a great time here, and I did love the food.  I think on any normal day, I would have loved to give this restaurant five stars.  The reason I'm taking two stars off is because I really really had my heart set on the rabbit or the lamb, but I couldn't get either.  The day I came in, the restaurant had served the last rack of lamb, so I tried to settle for the rabbit.  My second problem?  When the waitress asked if it was okay to bring the rabbit out rare, I asked if it could be prepared med rare.  She told me she had asked for a previous customer and the chef would not cook rabbit past rare.  Disappointed, I settled for my third choice, fish.  The fish was extremely juicy, tender and had a delicious citrusy flavor. I've heard a lot of rumors about how flavorless British food can be, but boy does thus this Chef knock down every stereotype.  The fish was impeccable - beautifully seasoned, perfectly cooked, and just exploded with flavor. For dessert we had a chocolate cake dish with pomegranate. I think this is my new favorite combination. Definitely beats chocolate and strawberry or chocolate wi raspberry any day of the week! I would love to come back and try some of the other dishes on another trip to London some day.  Although this time, I really hope I can get my first choice dish.

5z6tMKdhQ_varAMlHPDnoA.text: When this first opened in 2007 (or 08, I can't remember) I binged on it.  I just couldn't eat or drink enough there as everything was good, everytime.  As I was working in St James it was just about close enough that (with a bit of effort) I could make it my local. 20 or 30 times later I still loved it. Having moved jobs and with fewer excuses to visit it I revisited it today for a Sunday set lunch and will re binge in the near future.  If you want hearty gastro Anglicised food come here. If you want a pie, or a chunk of leg of some non descript animal stewed for 7 hours or a earthy terrine or some other solid food (almost an English version of Lyonnaise cuisine) this is the place to go.  The food is a bit less fussy than its sister restaurant in Waterloo, but it is smack bang in the centre of town, has awesome excited (in the food) staff, good wines and enjoyable house wines and along with the fact that you can get reservations here, it makes it just about perfect.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Interior
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

0TkXPGcvJIdVMGp-AA0X0w.text: First of all, the name of the restaurant is original eh? =)Honestly the service here is one of the best so far I've experiencd in London - just really friendly, unpretentious and cosy service by waiters/waitresses who love food. The menu is british which means lots of gamey birds, venison, pies, rillets, fries, cheese, etc. I had the rabbit rillet as a starter which was a bit dry and flavourless. However, I might be a bit biased since the week before i had the MOST amazing duck rillet that can not be compared to anything!|As my main, i had some a whole bird (forgot what type -either quail or partridge) which w as a bit difficult to eat since my knife/fork skills are HORRIBLE! I ended up just picking it up with my hands and gnawing away on the bones; while a waitress politely placed a bowl of water to rinse the grease off my face. Anyways, this place also has a good selection of wines to go along with the meal which can be quite a rarity at mid priced restaurants. Tip for readers: Make sure to call ahead and make reservations!

PDOXVs-P3DOr6ww474nayw.text: Dinner for 6. Took the wine recommendation which was perfect. Beef was cooked just right and the diverse menu was interesting and most importantly tasty!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

b1eN3uIRJNRFmSMPjw3ezQ.text: Classic British food done well. Came here in March with some friends for lunch and have been meaning to write a review for ages!A step above your classic pub fare and truly delicious for it. We shared the chicken liver pate and rillettes to start with - the pate disappeared sharpish, the rillettes were less popular. I followed this by a bean and vegetable soup, my friends had a rabbit salad and confit de canard if I recall - everyone raved about their food.Dessert was a divine pistachio cake, or which I could have eaten three slices...Really loved the laid back atmosphere of this place, that still serves good beer but let's the food shine through.I hope Great Queen Street gets the recognition it deserves, although once it is awarded it's first star it will be even harder to get a table!

JNwlzWS3I09698ZR3T47VA.text: Can't get over this place and want to return immediately! Came here very late on a Wednesday night (they serve until 10:30!) and just ordered a course each but that was enough to hook me for more. Staff are beyond friendly, atmosphere is super cozy and cocktails are reasonable prices. -Chickpea pancake: All sorts of YUM!-Ling with beetroot & walnut sauce: Hellz yes.-Dover sole fillets: Does come with teensy bones but the fish falls right off them and is breading/cooking is perfection. Def get with a side of tasty chips.

VPft4o4ibno7zNbIWS1OQQ.text: Came here for the lobster and the meal was great! The only thing I can criticize is the amount of salt on the chips, it was way too salty. Never the less, me and my SO had an excellent time due to the good service and affordable, delicious food and drinks. I would happily recommend this place to anyone who are looking for a good meal in Soho!

9Y-hCoTP2nwBO6NiT5W-pw.text: GQS's menu is unpredictable, but reliably unique and delicious!  Not that I don't love fish and chips from a pub, but this place is way above and beyond "food," into the realm of what one may unpretentiously term "cuisine."It's a wonderful spot to take your family or a larger group for a lingering dinner.  Many dishes are designed to share between several people, so coming by yourself will restrict your options (as I learned my first time here).The waitstaff is friendly, knowledgable and helpful, and they all speak with real love of their craft.  However, because they'll take the time to have a friendly chat, it means they're not the quickest.  I wouldn't recommend coming here to try a quick bite if you have any place to be.It's just too bad I don't live in London, or I'd enjoy coming back again and again to savor their next culinary revelations!

tBUbaW5v3kufX-GPPifmfQ.text: A chinese friend recommended this place. It was fully booked, but then they offer you first come first serve seats at the bar. You can wait for that in the downstairs, rather basic, cocktail bar. So off we went. We got two seats at the bar in 10 minutes.I actually preferred eating at the bar. Also gives you a good view of the semi open kitchen. Always a good sign. Another good sign is when a restaurant has daily specials. We had what they call a 'Crab Custard', which was a Crab mousse, as an appetizer from the specials. Very nice. We also ordered some cold haring. Very refreshing. We shared the appetizers, so that made for a good combination.We took one of the specials as main course. A classic I haven't seen on a menu for ages and which I remember eating in my childhood, growing up on the french border, from a french canned brand: Cassoulet. The very friendly waiter warned us that it was quite a heavy dish and had to be ordered for two. Sharing is caring. It was a good choice: the duck was excellent and they added some blood sausage to give it a British twist. Maybe one negative was that there weren't enough beans and sauce. But I might be wrong, I only have a canned history with Cassoulet.We finished sharing some very sweet apple pie with clotted cream. The bill was reasonable and we were full and happy.

gBK_9YgXiWujbAO4JqpdcA.text: I am so impressed with this restaurant. Everything I ate was incredibly delicious. The service is excellent and everyone is well informed about the dishes and seasonal ingredients. They have small plates and entrée-sized plates - all are great for sharing. I had dinner with three friends and we ordered a pumpkin dish, beef ribs, rabbit, curried aubergines, cauliflower and courgettes. I probably could have continued to order because everything was so well-prepared and wonderful!Cocktails are strong and arrive in small glasses, and you can also purchase a cookbook if you want to try this at home. This is a great find and a fantastic place to experience modern British fare where it really shines. I will definitely return the next time I am in London. What a great dining experience!

O62CDXVJiKUp-k14XC9FnQ.text: Great Queen Street features all sorts of seafoods and has very good quality. The oysters rocked as much as the cured sea trout. The homemade drinks are highly recommended but also a little pricey. The sole was super fresh and the kids loves the fries. All in all a rockstar dining option. Keep it up.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

ZacTuvfLxH2Ckeewe0y3Vg.text: Not sure why this place is so loved.  Menu was really unappealing when we were there, and our family of four tried three different dishes.  Really so-so, especially for the price.  Bread was good, but rest of the food just wasn't doing it for us.

skuo2nMCZdFvSoL7lmmZYQ.text: Wow. Everything is yummy. Stop by for lunch before or after a visit to the British Museum. Nice ambiance.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

tOQUI3DvzeTszxsBqt8xBQ.text: One of our go to place in London. They've usually got a nice rabbit pie on the menu, which is super tasty.

kl4wM8cg50Lzx78jRDxsnw.text: Absolutely LOVED this place. We got the shepherd's pie and this tomato soup that were TO DIE FOR. That crust was..... amazing. It's sad that their menu is seasonal, because I would go to London just for that food.

IlVOL7wy0zk12-WLwXTKag.text: A warming hearty meal in a warming hearty place. I caught up with a good friend here for dinner; she'd been before but it's somewhere I've often walked past and noticed it looking busy. Last Friday eve was the perfect opportunity for me to try it out.The interior is warm and welcoming with high end restaurant touches merged into a more informal gastropub setting. My ex-housemate shares a common characteristic with me in being ten minutes late for most things, so we arrived about the same time to be seated at a candlelit wooden table for two near the bar counter.The wine menu has a good spread of price points though doesn't tell you the grape variety for many of the bottles, so unless you're very up to speed on the names of the individual producers in each region you're somewhat flying blind. We asked our friendly waitress about some of the reds or what she'd recommend with lamb, and though I'm sure she must've been tempted to blag it, credit to her that she admitted she wasn't sure and she'd ask her more oenophilic manager. She reported back with some useful info and we were able to pick a full-bodied one that we both loved. Always good to ask on these things - life's too short to drink bad wine, right?The food menu changes daily with plenty of roasted meats and comforting sounding options. We both picked the lamb which nicely cancelled out any food envy - though that struck later when we saw a huge steak and ale pie arriving for two at the table next to us which looked great fun to dig into. The lamb was an excellent choice though - the meat nicely tender and pink, cooked with peppers, aubergines and anchovy. I wasn't sure about the anchovy part but you couldn't taste it in isolation, and altogether it was a decent-sized hearty dish that went well with new potatoes to share. The pleasingly sharp knife to get stuck in was also a welcome touch.The setting was so lovely we happily whiled away a good few hours chatting and enjoying our choice of wine. They did occasionally have a few people standing at the bar counter - and thus right next to our table - waiting to be seated, and one of them managed to drop a glass which smashed quite close to our feet. Just as we'd shot them an unimpressed look of course I managed to knock our little pepper pot off the other side of the table too. It cracked into 3 pieces which we propped back together against our empty wine bottle before leaving (childish I know but it seemed like a fun little jigsaw at the time) so err apologies to the restaurant when they found it!We went for the three-types-of-cheese plate for dessert which was the perfect way to end on a high, though far too much cheese for the two of us to finish. We gave it our best effort though - it was a good complement of a soft goats cheese, a blue and a hard all served with tasty oatcakes. It's not an everyday type of place and the bill came to £40 a head for a main, dessert and wine which felt about right for this place. There's a lot of competition around this level but I'll be adding it to the date night shortlist. Best suited for a special cosy dinner I think - they can accommodate groups but most of the tables are for two.

iBbwkQoDeXK9Vu3F8RitOw.text: We enjoyed this place. I would like to give a higher rating but there were a few things holding me back.Ambiance: lot of energy in the place, nicely set up, and casual.Service: our server Elena from Florence was very helpful, efficient, suggested a wonderful wine and made dining here a pleasant experience. Food: Overall, we loved the food. We started with potted shrimp and pickled cucumbers and a special pork belly app. Both were tasty and just the right portion. We decide to share the suckling pig main plate. It was HUGE, we could never finish the dish. My wife wanted to order ravioli as an app not a main but the chef refused to do so. No worries.The suckling pig was delicious, hard (maybe a bit too hard) skin and soft, flavored pork. We put a small dent in the dish. It was tasty. The servers packaged the leftovers and we gave them to a homeless person. Overall, a good experience.

27cF16bIPQWEwMd1324GIA.text: Great service, drinks and food.  Good location in Covent Gardens.  Since they were crowded and we had a family of 7, they even seated us in the lower level and we had private dining!  Amazing food!!  Be sure to try the steak pie.

PpERTFTrm66ZrzfdGzn9-g.text: We were looking forward to our dinner here all week, but we must have chosen an off night. Some dishes were amazing, but others were just so so. The gazpacho was incredible, with pieces of sweet cantaloupe to balance out the tart and spice of the soup. My wife loved her shrimp, mango, and avocado salad. Where dinner fell down was in the mains. There are some things my wife doesn't like to eat, and somehow every single one of them was on the menu that night. I got the cuttlefish, and my wife got the pasta, but compared to the menu we had seen earlier in the week, we were disappointed. They change the menu based on what's available, and while that makes for fresh, inventive food, it also means that you're not sure exactly what you're going to see on the menu.

19TqmkFyCw6lArf7Z5jEmw.text: A cozy and intimate restaurant that was perfect for date night.  We were catching a comedy show across the street at Soho Comedy Club so this was a very convenient spot for a pre-show meal.We ordered the lobster meal for two (a large lobster and potatoes) and also a bottle of wine.  The service was extremely accommodating, allowing us to taste a few different wines before settling on a decision.  They were very friendly and the entire place had a very mom and pop feel that was also classy and elegant.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Lobster dinner for two!

e3ooOCIQQTlBLAQbsq4IWw.text: Update from 2013. Still very nice, but ..... just not the same. Maybe it was our selection of a Pork and Bacon pie vs. the Rabbit pie. Would I go here again oh yes, would I dream about it. Don't think so.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Pork and Bacon Pie

618oAMynygM1Ao-3ntLKlA.text: Sometimes, Yelp lets you down. The best part of this place by far was the sourdough bread, which can go toe to toe with San Francisco's best. And they seem to know it - it was featured in both my app and main, as well as being provided on its own. Food-wise, we were very disappointed. The best dish was probably the smoked eel salad, which contained plenty of eel. The potted shrimp, on the other hand, was a cold, nutmeg-shrimp flavored spread and a piece of toast. Odd, and not in a good way. On to mains: the partridge was overcooked, and tasted like very dry chicken. The grouse, meanwhile, was the most bizarre dish of the night. It was cooked correctly, and had a nice gamey flavor profile on its own, so really no more dressing was needed. However, it also contained the following:-A side dish of gravy, to be poured on top (flavor profile #2)-A side dish of cheesy, pasty stuff, which you were then supposed to dip the meat in (flavor profile #3)-A couple of spoonfuls of cranberry sauce under the bird (flavor profile #4)-A spread of pate on toast coating the bottom of the dish on a piece of toast (flavor profile #5)To quote Annie Hall - "what, no pineapple?". This dish was far too messy to be enjoyable in any way.  Also, note that GQS is punishingly loud. I could hear individual conversations from four or five other tables, and this was on a Monday night. That plus the bad food made us want to get out of there as soon as possible and forget the whole thing. No beers on tap save for one watery cask ale (not deducting points for this, just FYI). Service was fine, if you could hear it above the din.

x0Bar_VjY08ToER4BeVsWg.text: This restaurant was excellent. The staff was friendly and extremely helpful with the menu. There was a lot of variety, and when we asked for recommendations it became even more difficult to choose because it all sounded delicious. But most importantly the food was fantastic, and they offered really good portions.Doing a quick dollar to pound conversion in my head, I'd say it was pretty well priced, too. I will absolutely be returning next time I'm in London.

lHNzBcwp7X_c--cnrUP1gQ.text: It's been a while since I've been to this pub for dinner - and thought it would be good to go again since we weren't sure where to go for dinner before watching a show at the Peacock theatre.  (Little did we know there are so many new restaurants on Kingsway!)  Book a reservation - it gets really busy especially on a weekend evening.  We were lucky to get an early dinner reservation for 5:45 - as well as mentioning that we had to be out before 7 for our show.  Luckily we ordered quite quickly because 2 of the dishes we wanted take quite a while to prepare.  For the 5 of us, we ordered the lamb shoulder and the steak and ale pie.  They warned us that it'll take about 45 minutes to prepare but it was so worth it... even though we had to inhale our food in the end.The lamb shoulder was pure comfort.  It looks overwhelming at first but the portion is meant for 3 people (or a really hungry pair!)   Definitely the dish to get.  I heard from other friends that go regularly that they do tend to run out so get there a bit early if you don't want to be disappointed.  I had a bit of the steak and ale pie and it was delicious.  They change the menu around each day. I'd be interested to try their sunday roast one of these weekends.  Great queen street - you definitely represent gastro pub at its best.

AGAjytwg3zG7wRunJNtUhg.text: This was one of our favorite places we dined while visiting London! The service and food were both amazing and the atmosphere was even better. Definitely worth trying while in London!

5sovLGmggU-buk4PqAgMLg.text: I very much enjoyed my experience at Great Queen Street. The decor is super cute, the food was inventive and tasty, and the wine list was top notch. Their wine list really stands out with thoughtful selections, including an orange wine section and a "pudding wines" section (for dessert wines). And the service was friendly, knowledgeable, and hip. Standouts on menu: ham hock and rabbit terrine with leeks in mustard vinaigrette, ceps and Parmesan polenta cake, as well as merengue and raspberry custard for two. I did not have anything I did not like, actually, it's just that those items were extra delicious. Would definitely go back if I lived in London. :(

XLOCRC0kGa1yLCE1SZQoIg.text: Summary-- The best food we had in our 5 days in London. My husband and I went to Nopi and Dishoom the first few days, came to Greet Queens Street on the 4th day, love it so much we made another reservation for the 5th day! We totally ordered 6 different dishes and every one of it surprised us! The waiter and waitress were all very very friendly, cheerful, and accommodating. I told the waiter that it's the best meal I had in London, and I really mean it! Love the food and service both! My husband also loves how the menu is always changing, it means the chef really cares about the food they offer! Highly, highly recommend it! And we will definitely go there again the next time we are in London!  Detail-- This restaurant is indeed full of surprises! We went there for dinner and love it so much that we made another lunch reservation for the same week.  At dinner, we had the lamb shoulder  for main dish to share and the potato dish (I forgot the name), pig cheek for starter. The cream with the potato was so good, we (two ppl) finished the whole thing. I'm not good with words so I can only tell you the lamb shoulder was very tender and juicy, the carrots with it was very sweet. We love every single dish we ordered!  For lunch, we had the beef and ale pie. It wasn't usually offered at lunch, but at the previous dinner, the waitress was so nice to help us "pre-order" it so the chef can prepare it just for us!  I'm usually not a fan for pie crust, but I love this one!! The starters- Smoked eel salad and the fried octopus (?) was also delicious!

2nvpdXGxFJ3WOjriBdUlGg.text: Small local place. Excellent food and service. Takes reservations which is nice and a rotating hand pumped ale of the day. Good steak and ale pie.

kx4PVkScjxoO1pkAxCcVPA.text: What a quaint laid back restaurant with unexpectedly great food in a central area of town! I had the sirloin with peppercorn sauce and the meat was quality, decently priced and came in a good portion size. Others had the fish (for 2+ individuals) and were very satisfied. The service was also amiable with our waiter engaging in our table's jokes several times and even accommodating dessert orders even after the kitchen had closed!Definitely stop by if you're in the area!

Aj_kh3RGu7RAM7xL4n1YBQ.text: This was easily our best meal in London.  We were very fortunate to score two seats at the end of the bar on a busy Saturday night.  Service was spotless from start to finish, and the atmosphere was very warm.After trying a few sips of wine, we settled on the spanish red, which was perfect. We shared an app of duck hearts and bacon on toast, which was unique and delicious.  That was followed by the octopus stew and the duck breast.  The octopus was excellent with is it's mildly chewy, rich seafood sauce, but the duck was phenomenal.  It was one of the best plates I've had all year.  Perfectly cooked breast over mushy peas with a side of black pudding.  It was London fare that was perfectly elevated.I wanted to go back for a second night in a row, but unfortunately it wasn't in the cards.  If you're nearby, do not pass this one up.

RySpndDfR6uPppcXRJzrJg.text: We loved this place. It's run by Spaniards, and they serve a strange melange of traditional British fare with continental delicacies.  The atmosphere is casual and the service was friendly and attentive.  We had the meat pie, which was fantastic, and the fried zucchini flower, along with salad and port and sherry after.  Just a sweet little restaurant run by people who care about food and service.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

QGOt64nR6Ns5A_kqpQ5vVQ.text: Great comfort food. Very tasty and friendly staff.Eat the Oglet and my wife had the wild mushrooms. Would definitely come back again.

1dDL1cb2HxVYCX5WflHvNw.text: This is a great place. I visited this place some years ago, but I was very pleased and impressed by the food, workers who are very friendly.The price is very convinable for everybody and menu is very rich and diverse.I ate lamb sweetbreads, pea puree and mint and i fell in love,it was taste and very delicious.

t8kqNdtBQY9AJ0NO55LpYw.text: Had a lovely dinner there on a busy Friday night. Three girlfriends, we arrived early and the staff were charming and accommodating. We decided to share a table full of starters and GQS did not disappoint: the food was delicious, fresh, creative and well presented. We lingered to the last and were treated with care. Lovely food and wine and a great location. Places like this are hard to find in central London - we'll be visiting again I'm certain

tQ5cSS52So2bxQQIeWG6yg.text: Quaint quality place!  Close to the British museum  so just a short walk for a nice meal before or after!  Delicious food and great service!!!!  Highly recommend and I can't wait to come again!  Also Michelin recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Delicious!!!  Pork and spinach with great sauce!!!

wfxvT0GuVCZfneJZSXOQBA.text: Food was very good, but service was not. Waitress didn't get our complete order and never came back to check on us. The restaurant was not busy, with customers at only four tables.

5p4LiA6a9gViKHSjbjqvbA.text: Really enjoyed my meal here at Great Queen Street. We received a warm welcome and helpful advice on wine choices (I thought the muscadet was lovely) and some very good bread and butter. I started my meal with two delicious oysters while my friend opted for a quince and manchego salad. I'd been hoping to try one of the more "English" dishes such as the cold beef and horseradish, which sounded great but my friend wanted to share the Moroccan chicken with couscous and olives. Although it would not have been my choice I did really enjoy it and it was a really generous portion.Only negative was that it took ages and several requests for the bill at the end, but the waiter acknowledged that which I appreciated.Would highly recommend this restaurant for a varied menu and quality, reliable food.

pe88XBjVVPffYsYy-kX69A.text: Suet crusted rare breed chicken pie. The end. Just kidding. Also got the venison and pork terrine. And the quince tart tartine, which we had to cancel on account of being stuffed. The crust is the superstar here. The suet was like a perfectly crunchy top layer and where the crust meets the chicken creates almost a dumpling like belly. Also, I was impressed with how tender the chicken was and had an amazing seasoning I could quite identify. The terrine was also tasty. Nothing really stood out other than the fact that went perfectly with the stewed plumsMan do I wish we would have had room for the quince tart tartine. Overall, what a great, homey, well-executed meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Venison and pork terrine
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Salad
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Slice off hockey pie

jcfy94o8BTVwQWrBIMJ6RQ.text: Wow wow wow wow wow!! My friend recommended this place for a nice place to take a favourite couple to celebrate their engagement. I wasn't sure if having such an important event at a never-tried place, but she positively promised me it was worth it. She raced about the pies, as this is one of the few remaining places that does suet crust, and said we could not be disappointed.The 4 of us thought the menu looked fantastic and decided to go for the 6-hr slow cooked lamb shoulder, which serves 3. Of course, I had to get the steak and ale pie, which serves 2, so we had 5 mains to share! So naturally we added chips and gratin dauphinois to our order as well. The smell from the lamb was almost more impressive than the flavour... ok not really as it was to die for, but you know what I mean. The pie was being scrumptious and I owe my friend a giant high-5. We tipped the night with 2 puddings to share, and the super fab staff even gave our engaged couple a glass of champers each. Love love love this place!!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Apple tarte tatin- caramelly and gorgeous
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Steak and kidney pie with a proper suet crust
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Lamb shoulder, steak and kidney pie, chips, potato dauphinois

3d-gpB9pJdAVm0B2ecdw2Q.text: The duck for two was ample and tasted great. Small space but the meals came out in good time. Left very happy with my meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

5383zvknpmHbq58RAWXBMA.text: Had the lamb shoulder for 3 with dauphinoise potatoes (Iike au gratin). Super tasty and probably best lamb I've ever had.  Curried Chickpeas were excellent as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

4tq3wxY27loXVPb3TAGZ9Q.text: The steak there was great.  The chicken pot pie was not bad.  The ambiance is nice..intimate as dim.  The service was great!   The nice lady was very personable and even sat down with us to let her know if her favorite restaurants in Paris.  Definitely enjoyed the dinner there.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Huge chicken pot pie.

hLtc7-Y6AXUOb42N9PKMhQ.text: Really nice place for solo dining. The manager recommended the hake and he was absolutely right -- so delicious. Camped out here for a while with my kindle on a business trip and was treated well.
