GjLwiWjkU05P0880elsVvw.text: Meat pie.  That's all you really need to know about this place.  There are a lot of other things to try at this place, but if you're dining for two, I highly recommend the meat pie.  It's really filling and really delicious.  The booze here is also pretty cheap, so have a few drinks and indulge in one of the meatiest, thick meat pies around.

uxcinVMydyCK4kDKQ2_IoQ.text: The menu looked good online but our food was really very awful and the service was worse. I cannot recommend that you go else where strongly enough.My wife I were very hopeful after looking at the menu onine. The appitizer was so forgettable, that I can only remember that it was slow and mediocre. I ordered the steak. It turned out to be so tough and stringy that I could not chew it. My wife's fish stew was equally disappointing.As bad as the food was, the service was worse. The manager for some reason was refusing to seat couples at open 2 person tables. The place is small. There were 3 perfectly good tables open. He "created" a new table six inches from the end of the bar, then proceed to congregate six inches away from it with the other staff. He continues this trend, seating couples at the  bar as they arrived. By the end if our meal there were 5  two person  tables open, and maybe 3 additinal  couples eating at the bar. My point, don't eat here unless you love a horrible seat.Our waitress was in explicably absent. There were only maybe 6 to 10 table and 4 or 5 saff. However, they were slow , not helpful, and had a general attitude that they were completely unconcerned with providing a good dining experience.I suggest that you go  else where.

IUQ7rpBCRHEkGfdFMnK4pQ.text: Lovely, little restaurant! I enjoyed the lunch menu and the atmosphere so much that I went back with a few days later with some friends for dinner. Everyone was very nice to me when I went there by myself and later on everyone in our group were satisfied with the service. I highly recommend this restaurant.

LmpzLI6YYjDZIui-MzXciA.text: The best thing about this restaurant is that the menu is always changing. You will never eat the same thing twice here as they adapt what they have to the best of what is available. I frequent this place regularly and I can honestly say I have never had a bad dish.Traditional British prepared game is probably what I'd say they do best here. The service is top notch, although depending on how busy it is, it can be quite slow. It can also be quite loud in this establishment and the tables are close together so you can easily hear other peoples conversations. They do have tables in the alcoves of the windows at the front, which if you are lucky enough to grab those, could be quite romantic. But the deeper you get towards the back, the louder, and hotter it becomes.They also have a spectacular drinks selection, with a lot of home made spirits and cordials. Their homemade ginger mixer is great. Perfect for a mule or dark and stormy. They also have a bar downstairs which is never as busy as I think it should be as it is pretty awesome.Overall - this place is top notch and I love it. It can be VERY busy, so a reservation would be best, or if you can go at an off-peak time.

jFKFbcWlp1-LBZAtVqNONg.text: My husband and I have now dined here more times that I can count with various friends and co-workers. He has now been quoted on more than one occasion as saying "This is exactly the kind of restaurant that I would like to run if I ever ran a restaurant!" - To say we love this place would be an understatement! It has become easily our favorite place in London because it is fantastic, wholesome, generously portioned food that changes with the seasons and yet delivers consistently elevated flavors every time. The ambience is casual or even intentionally rustic with beautifully worn exposed wooden tables that allow the focus to be on the food and the company instead of feigned refineries. Though they take reservations, we've never had trouble getting one on short notice. The staff is wonderfully well versed in the menu and make recommendations readily. They are attentive and friendly and serve everything with the same care that you imagine they would in their own homes. On one occasion we ordered far too much food (as they have many Main options that are portioned for 2 or 3 people and in our efforts to try everything on the menu, we have issues with moderation) and three waiters worked quickly to pack up an embarrassing amount of food for us to take home. We ate like kings for a week!

4mFcTfFZPRt1m6k6_w2UTw.text: We ordered duck ragu, chicken pot pie, amaretto sour drink and raspberry prosciutto. All was great! Our waitress Ana was very helpful and sweet. Overall was a great way to end our last day in London.

gMce1qhtXmv07Pn-midTDA.text: Four star dinner with one star service. Had a reservation at 8:30 and arrived at 8. The bartender was kind enough to greet us and let us know that our table was available already and seated us. After about 15 minutes of sitting, she came back and apologized, brought menus, bread for the table and a carafe of water. She didn't ask a about drink orders and I figured she'd be back soon. 20 additional minutes later, a waiter who had been taking care of nearby tables approached and quickly asked what we wanted. No greeting, no apologies, just quickly tell me what you want. We ordered drinks and all of our entrees at that time. The drinks arrived quickly and the food soon followed - they were all brought by runners(not our waiter -Sebastian) Excellent rabbit, wonderful blood sausage. But- we never saw our waiter again until he showed up at 9 and asked if we were done. We had all been planning on a few additional cocktails and beer, but by then, our drinks had been empty for 20 minutes and we just wanted to leave. He quickly brought  the bill, ran it through the card machine and tore off my copy without a word. No smile, no thanks for coming, nothing. We just spent the last week in Paris where we were treated very well by the servers- I expected London to be superior, but just found this to be the least welcoming server I've ever had. Go for the excellent food , but not if you expect to be treated well.

jw-RQtS6kbZqUy9TlmB2Tg.text: Lovely place with great ambiance. The steak was cooked to perfection. On the whole an ideal place to have your meal.

xqtgbDovxnAMgOXo5m7bgg.text: Had a wonderful meal here with some friends who were on honeymoon - wanted to take them somewhere super brity, and Great Queen fit the bill.  The casual atmosphere and flowing beer led to a night of great conversation, an amazing meal and hopefully a relaxing start of a wonderful honeymoon for our friends...We started with an order of shuck-yourself fresh peas, yogurt & cucumber soup and a rabbit terrine.  Right in season, the peas were sweet and delicious, the soup was fresh and tasty, and the terrine was firm but spreadable - this was my first terrine, and definitely not my last in the following months...but definitely one of the best comparatively.For our entree, we all decided on the veal shin for 4...which, let me tell you, was at least enough to feed a small village, and worth the 25 min wait.  The veal was presented on a huge serving platter, and after we all stuffed our faces, barely looked like we dented it.A side of roasted new potatoes completed the meal and left us all waddling out, sated from meat & buttery potato deliciousness.  We also left with a 2lb bag of leftovers that made excellent sandwiches the next day!  We will definitely be back again!

hOWgZvqrF9ENz2P3Z6MlTA.text: This a great friendly venue for some good honest dining, in the tradition of the english gastropub. You will have read it all in the other reviews but I wanted to add that it's not all meat'an'game, the fish courses are great too. I had a deliciously moist lemon sole with wild garlic butter. The flesh was cooked to perfection, falling off the bone invitingly. And although I was a little scared the wild garlic would completely overpower the delicate taste of the fish, it actually made for a great companion to the sole.

uAZrBr-qfO9HbQo_LuEnqQ.text: Fun place - interesting British dishes such as pig's cheek, guinea fowl and a few Euro ones like lomo. I liked a lot - the good points are the decor, general warmth, reasonable wine served also in 375ml carafes, unusual range of food. The smoked mackerel and beet starter was seriously good. The pumpkin pasta less so... but then my more "meaty" friends relished the rabbit medallions and aforementioned pig cheek. Go, but take a serious carnivore with you.

tEcf5O9oyrg4lnSyHxeRow.text: I just don't know what to think Nice venue and atmosphere. Starters were a bit lacklustre I think, for the price. Plate of sand eels, basically just like whitebait. Cold peas straight out of a very chilly fridge, some were really not that fresh, cold soup. Mains were good but portions I found a bit meagre. Had to order new potatoes and greens (just cabbage) separately, small portions again. It was very good food, I had the duck with fennel, carrots and bacon. Honestly, I think I have had better, more flavoursome meals for the same price. This dish definitely needed something. Something to go with it, some sweet potato, carrot and swede mash, some real bulk. It was beautifully cooked, and tasty, but just atop a small bed of vegetables.I found the young waitress just a bit rude and a touch patronising, I am sorry to say. I was with a bunch who are a bit old and past it, and they are hard of hearing and a bit fussy, I found her not all that patient. So sorry to be writing this review after reading so many others. I wouldn't return here. I'd like to give this place a 4. Consider this a 3.6 out of 5.

UPROIQV39yf5jXQE79S0IQ.text: [Non-photo Review] For full article, see: wp.me/pwXBH-uP  Long Live the Queen I had been looking forward to meeting fellow food blogger Craig Linton (twitter: @craigdlinton) for a few weeks after I invited him to meet up for lunch a while back. Luckily, I wasn't too nervous as I had already met another food blogger a few months back for lunch (see a post about that meal here). Although it is always a bit disconcerting meeting someone you've emailed and tweeted with but never met in the flesh, I had the sneaking suspicion that we were going to get on, given our seemingly similar attitudes towards restaurants and food, which are of course the two most important things in the world (Mrs. LF is going to kill me if she reads this). So, in the middle of our two places of work, Great Queen Street (GQS) awaited. The little sister of some British gourmets' favourite (and I cringe as I write the word) 'gastropub', GQS has no real name, no website, and no gimmicks. It is all simple wood and dim lighting inside, with informal but fairly knowledgeable staff. Like so many London restaurants today (St John and Bocca di Lupo spring to mind), the daily menu is presented on a loose sheet of paper, inferring that the menu changes daily and is probably more or less seasonal. And GQS checked all those boxes. The menu was quite traditionally British, and the simple, hearty fare sounded good to me as it had been a rather long and cold walk to get there. Unsurprisingly, I arrived on time, and was shown to a little square table for two, where my blind, male food blogger date was to join me. It was all a bit weird, but luckily I had seen a photo of him online so more or less knew what to look for. A bit over-anxious, I waved haphazardly to the next dude through the door based on just the faint outline of his face, who luckily happened to be the man himself. Phew. After a long and enjoyable getting-to-know-you chat, we were scouring the menus like to men on a mission, trying to make wise selections in the presence of the seasoned foodie across the table. Decisions made, we continued with a very engaging and pleasant discussion, until the thing that united us finally arrived. Grub time. Getting Down to Bi'ness Some brown bread and butter had arrived, so we both had a small piece of it. It was pretty average and there's nothing much more to say about it. I now eagerly awaited my main. 5/10. I had heard a lot about Old Spot pork but had never knowingly tried it, so despite some reservations about a room temperature dish (that's how they serve it) on a cold November day, I went for it. Luckily, I was not disappointed. It was a very simple dish with three main components. The pork was sliced to a medium thickness and the circles of fat were left in tack around the rim. It definitely had a unique full, round, mouth filling flavor that I hadn't experienced before. It was surprisingly interesting and had me going back for more, especially when combined with the tangy yet slightly sweet and in-season crab-apple jelly. Because the side of greens we ordered was so delicious with its naughty, slightly creamy mustard sauce, which had a nice streak of acidity, I sort of ignored the little salad that came on my plate. This was a shame, because when I tasted it as an afterthought, I found it was actually quite good and it would have been a nice little accompaniment to the meat and jelly. Overall, then, a simple and accomplished dish. 8/10. I had ordered a glass of Beaujolais to go with my pork, thinking a soft, easy-drinking fruity wine would marry well with the flavors. It was brought out in a little ridged tumbler (like a small water glass you get in a bistro), as was Craig's Portuguese red, which I thought was taking the minimalism a tad too far. It's okay to serve wine on tap into a glass like that (like a place I went to in Venice once called Da Marisa), and Beaujolais after all is a very casual wine drunk with simple food in France, but I like my wine to breathe a bit and think a normal little wine glass would have been better. Rants aside, the wine did what I hoped it would and was a nice sipping partner for my late Old Spotted friend. It's worth noting that before tasting my own dish, I was quite jealous of Craig's main course just on the looks. It reminded me of the hearty beef stroganoff my mom used to make us when I was a teenager. Luckily, he didn't think I was a complete freak when I asked if he wanted to taste some of my dish, and even offered up a bit of his beef. The meat itself was very soft and tender, having been stewed for a long time, and the sauce it was bathing in was not bad at all. If I had to label it, I'd say it was sort of a European beef curry sauce, with its richness being supported and enhanced by a nice underlying spice (the 'devil' bit, I supposed) that ruminated and lingered in the mouth for a good while. I didn't taste the rice or the egg, but the bit of meat and sauce I

FCufXK4_cfulnHIG7lxoDQ.text: alright.  i'm home sick, and believe it or not i'm actually tired of watching svu episodes so i suppose i should catch up on reviews.  that said, i'm highly drugged so i can't promise my usual wit.after a 3 course dnr lunch at the ledbury, and 6 hours of solid eating and drinking i nearly yakked when i saw the allegedly 4-5 person lamb shoulder at great queen street.  it's really more for 6-7 and we failed to account for the presence of a vegetarian among us.  smoked mackerel starter was a standout, and potatoes dauphinoise, which i'm sure are just as cream-injected as any other cheesy potatoes, somehow seemed pleasantly light.  dunno how they did that.  the main dish of course, was the main dish: a 24 hr braised lamb shoulder (i remember thinking it was incongruous that we were like: 24 hr braised lamb shoulder please, and they were like: that'll take about 45 mins. . .but i later used my sophisticated understanding of mathematics to deduce that they probably braised it for 23.25 hours prior to our ordering of it), melt off the bone, swimming in meat juice.  i can't wish i hadn't eaten as much earlier, because lunch at the ledbury was awesome too, but i guess i can say, i wish i had replacement stomachs for days like this?

-Xk1IUaL1WAiZb2mhRh-Zw.text: The three of us decided to eat here before heading off to the ROH. We told the staff we didn't have a lot of time to spare so they made an effort to get our food out fast. Unfortunately by rushing, they ended up giving us half of someone else's order by mistake and before the waiter could grab the plate to correct the order my daughter was already digging into the daube of beef. We also had the plaice and the lamb neck. instead of the kale we ended up with brussel tops and some roasted potatoes. I didn't mind since I've never had brussel tops before and they ended up being pretty damn good. My favorite was the lambs neck. The meat was tender and juicy and I had to steal bits when my wife wasn't looking. I had the plaice and it was the best fish I've had in the UK so far. The daube was decent but there were other things on the menu I'd go for before ordering that again. Overall despite the mistakes it was a great meal, cozy old English atmosphere, and definitely made my list of go-to places in London.

j-bcUyhCQzptSnsjVJpqvA.text: The steak was phenomenal here - nice cozy restaurant with decent wine. The salad is uninspiring, but the service is good and its a nice simple place for a meal, although it can get expensive

S8BxY4Zjoq5kMR1c9JgmUA.text: this is a great relaxed eatery serving modern british cooking of a very good gastro pub standard. Not too pricey and a great ambience in the place. Everyone i went with thought it was lovely.

j_49n3KB7RGNd2J2TOJMrw.text: You know when you pick a restaurant and after the meal you're just like "NAILED IT!!!!"? Well, this is what happened here. The whole time I was thinking "Wow, I really picked a great place", and it wasn't just the prosecco. I've had this place on my mind for a while and we were going to see the ballet afterwords so this location was really good. So much had to do with the ambiance. I'm not sure what it was. It was just cozy and sweet and the tables were far enough apart where you didn't feel like people were too close but the tables were also small enough so you could hold your partners hand and the lights were pretty dim and the place was pretty small so it felt intimate but again not to squished. I was a huge fan of the menu because it had a lot of options (especially for us fellow pescatarians... yeah, I'm pescatarian at the moment ;) ). The star of the entire meal was the entree- sole with leeks and potato. We shared it and the portion was massive and so delicious. Really, that fish was mighty tasty and the sauce and seasoning complimented it so well and the addition of the potato and leeks was important to counter balance all the saltaaayyy. The other dishes were also delicious. Trout with pickled cucumber, salted anchovy salad and burrata with asparagus. All in all it was just a fantastic meal with great ambiance. I'd definitely come here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Sole with leeks and potato
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Potted trout with pickled cucumber and toast
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Salted anchovies with salad and egg

XWesYeyWy6PZ9_vzD_D0eg.text: - pork loin was cooked perfectly, very tender, slightly pink- quail was enjoyable but difficult to eat, basically impossible with a knife and fork (but to be expected with any small bird) - ordered the warm chocolate pudding (which for americans is just chocolate lava cake)- orange sorbet w/ shortbread was light and refreshing with soft vanilla finish- recommend: lemonade- service was pleasant but neglectful - honorable mention to the downstairs bar- DO NOT order the orange rose, strong bitter finish that persists

G5dgC5BjbOlc2vvuvngYpA.text: What an amazing dinner experience! Great service, delicious food, and a unique interior! Large tables make it great for groups! Why I was here // my party of 7 were looking for a nice dinner place to end our day of sightseeing in London. Service // welcoming and attentive. They checked in often and were very helpfulAtmosphere // since it was dinner time, the ambiance was more funky lit. The interior was unique (very old timey feel) Food // omg everything about this dinner was great! - homemade ginger beer // 3.00 // yessss this was amazing! Love the strong kick of the ginger -appetizer // whitebait with mayo // sauce wasn't bad but I am not a huge fan of whole tiny fishy fish-appetizer // salad // also an interesting dish but very tasty. It seemed to consist of eggplant and asparagus over a nice cheese - main // suckling pig // super yummy! The outside was crispy and inside although slightly dry was still bursting with flavor. The sauerkraut and veggies paired well. Note that this dish serves more than one person. -main // lamb shoulder // super tender, melt in your mouth with tons of flavor! Served with potatoes gratin, this one was my fave! -note that this dish was for more than one person -main // quail // very tender and sooo good! Overall // this was the English feast that I dreamed about. Wish I could have tried dessert but I was so stuffed I couldn't have stomached another bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

dnyvaikzMllornLGq-Tuzw.text: Loved our dinner at great queen street. The waiter helped us select items as British food was new to us. We shared the chicken tarragon pie, warm rabbit salad, and stuffed croquette. They also had an extensive wine list. I would love to go back and try more items on the menu. Great place to have dinner in London!

bvYPVz9IUmvqWKE0ZPBL_Q.text: Hands down the best dining experience I had in a week of eating out in London. This place was spectacular. We were very lucky to get in without a reservation, as we came right at opening time for an early dinner. What made this meal special was that even the small touches were so well executed.The menu is daily, changing depending on what ingredients are at hand, which is always exciting. That sort of rustic, farm-to-table mentality is seen throughout out the menu. We started with the warm eel and sausage salad. While this may sound strange, it was fantastic. The eel was perfectly smoked, and the sausage was very flavorful. It all came together beautifully with a tangy vinaigrette.For mains, we had the duck with lentils and seafood stew. The duck was simply to die for, perfectly medium rare with crispy skin, on a bed of lentils with a very tasty herb sauce to spice them up. I would highly recommend whatever the duck main on the menu is, as they really nail cooking this protein. The seafood stew was decent, but nothing too special.For dessert, we split the giant apple tartine with Calvados ice cream. Mmmmmh! Definitely worth the ~15 minute wait as it takes to a ooey, gooey perfection. It was beautiful to look at, and even better to eat. The Calvados ice cream was excellent on top too, and was strong enough that the whole tarte was flavored with spirit. A beautiful combination.They also have an ever changing house beer/ale, which was a nice touch. There's a varied alcohol selection, for whatever budget, including plenty of £100+ bottles.If you're in central London, head to the Great Queen. Or better yet, get a reservation in advance. You won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Apple tartine for 2 topped with Calvados ice cream. Brilliant combination!
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Perfectly cooked duck on a bed of lentils. Fantastic.

bBCHXUaPuMa6uaQbuIWZvw.text: I had the Halibut with pureed fennel. The Halibut was the best I ever had.  My wife had Quail.  She loved it.  The salad dressing on the green salad was superb.  The service friendly.  Highly recommended.

ZdCXDzRJTQ0aFuNQ3C36EQ.text: Cozy and intimate place in Covent Garden with dim lighting, lively conversations and great food. The service was attentive, and waiters were great at recommending the right dishes.The razor clams with chorizo was perfectly cooked and beautifully decorated. I found it to be a tad salty, but that came from the combination with chorizo. The veal special was tenderly cooked to perfection. The meat was easy to cut and had the right flavor. The German pasta was lightly fried and very doughy. The beignets came out piping hot, were coated with sugar and came with raspberry jam and cream. I can see how this is be a crowd favorite!Overall a solid place to stop by. There's a cellar bar tucked away downstairs, which looked like the perfect place for date night.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Beignets with raspberry jam and heavy cream
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Razor Clams with chorizo
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Veal Special with German pasta

u18RgGZ3d1jiS8L0fOE67w.text: This is an interesting spot... the menu is definitely off the beaten path. After receiving such high reviews I was immediately deflated with my pick when My husband and I sat down to the menu. There were very few items on it that I saw Yelplisted, I'm sure they change it up frequently, but it was still a shocking selection. My husband and I had the house red wine (good but sweet) and a Manhattan (too much vermouth). We were struggled to find something we'd enjoy on the menu but settled with ham and cheese croquettes which were good, and for our entree we went with one of the shared dishes (we saw it go by and it looked beautiful!)- roasted oxtail with risotto. The ox was subpar, the inside pieces were moist and delicious. The outside bits were quite overcooked and dry. I will say with whatever chutney they had on top and the risotto, every bite could be delicious, but on its own, the ox didn't stand up. The service was odd - it didn't seem like we had a dedicated server and even though everyone seemed to be serving us, we felt neglected. We sat with empty glasses for quite a while when we first arrived and then again between rounds... including water.One of our servers saw us struggling with the menu and made no attempt to offer selections.I made a reservation as suggested but the place had plenty of seating - it was a week night though. I wouldn't recommend this restaurant.

EXlmAcUWlB-c7F5relvTAA.text: This is a very nice restaurant. We accidentally found it while strolling around. I believe most people made reservations but we were glad that the gracious host gave us a table too.The food was fantastic. We ordered two appetizers,  a Pork & Game terrine and a Stuffed Courgette. We were surprised how delicious they were.As for the main course, we had the Steak & Ale Pie for two. It was huge and can easily feed 3-4 people instead of just two.The pie had great chunks of meat with a hearty ale sauce. Absolutely delicious and very tasty. Too bad we over ate and did not try the desserts. We would definitely come back to this restaurant again the next time we are in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. The Steak & Ale Pie for two with chunky meat and ale sauce.
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Steak & Ale Pie for two
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. The Stuffed Courgette

PhtktmiGsleUPTS2ySgubg.text: It was intimidating at first.  The menu is very, very "chefy".  Weird names for things that actually turn out to be pretty normal.  We sat at the bar and the bartender was busy but tried to be attentive.  We had the Chicken pot pie ( I don't remember what the fancy name was but essentially that's what it was).  It was good.  Really didn't need to call it more than that but somehow they felt they needed to do that.  Wine was good.  overall, nothing special but good.

ZsukyWm3x50Z2KP5MKTTXQ.text: This was an amazing blend of bar/ comfort/ bit fancy restaurant-bar.  The chicken pie for 2, dessert and drinks were spot on, but the fried artichoke app was disappointing.  I would love to go back!

3Td2QfgV4ApOowvtpk2eWg.text: Best pub food I've had in London. High quality and modern twists on the classics with some fresh options like salads. Great service. I recommend making a reservation since it's small with only a few tables.

Ipx3MI9GClJl8xabQRGwDQ.text: We called at 6:00 pm on a Friday and were able to get a table for 4 at 9:30 that evening. Slightly disappointing at first because 3 or 4 menu items were already crossed out upon our arrival (like the mussels) but things went up from there. The steak and ale pie is A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. If you're a foreigner wanting to try this delicious British cuisine I could not recommend more. Definitely needs to be shared between 2 people but it tasted like a delicious slow cooked beef stew cooked inside the perfect homemade biscuit crust. It comes out piping hot!I also had the seafood ravioli which were a solid 4/5 but nothing compares to the steak and ale pie.Service was attentive and the food came fast. Definitely recommend calling and making a reservation or coming and trying to find a seat at the bar.

Q72wTGIOLUWpdX9ZEGriiA.text: GQS is a pub, or more accurately the very definition of a gastropub, taking pub fare and raising the quality and flavor level to make even tea-totalers come for a visit.The short rib pot pie was amazing. I don't even eat short rib, but I couldn't help myself when I saw someone at the next table order it. Everyone else loved their food too. Seriously, all the plates were scraped sparkling clean.Even better, it's in a great neighborhood in case you're interested in a pint or two before / after dinner.

GwarG8VkkVlvGEQXJdxJtA.text: Yummy eel salad, fish and dessert. Ordered the chicken pie as we saw lots of positive reviews.we all thought it was OK..the crust was pretty burnt hence  that was a little disappointing and the quail was nothing special. Overall, good meal.some things could have been better to make it amazing.Choose wisely, have an amazing meal. :)

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Sea bass
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Chicken pie
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Quail

5HZfRubmH9rfJuqlPuQkag.text: Simply delicious. While in london our tour guide joked that british food wasn't all that great. I have to disagree! Queen street was definitely our favorite meal while in london! We got the braised lamb which was fall off the bone and say so perfectly in sauce and sauteed kale and mash. I got the ricotta dumplings baked in a dish of mushroom tomato sauce. The ambiance was great, cool laid back and packed! We ate at the bar. We were shocked that not one person was on their phone while they dined/conversed. So refreshing! Dessert was amazing, even though we were full we ate the entire slice of strawberry tart. Moist soft buttery crust with sweet slightly tart (in a good way) strawberry filling in the center. Would definitely come back on our next visit to london!

zi7mf07_TMVF5e6cs5RSGg.text: Cute restaurant with great food and service!  The chicken pot pie was amazing!  Also got the beef and risotto - very good!  Fast service!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

AwojEngw78i2NjmqLR1i4Q.text: What a neat little restaurant that's off the beaten path. Their menu is eclectic and fresh, the service is wonderful, and the interior is gorgeous. Their bathroom is down some very narrow stairs so if you have any mobility issues be careful! Overall we all truly enjoyed our dinner here and highly recommend it!

skmOJ-wLn7l31G4HBQoEJA.text: Came here last night hoping for a bit of good old nostalgia. I had been here about 10 years ago with the man who is my husband now.Great Queen Street was a quite upmarket pub then, and we shared a rather good chateaubriand. Sadly this is now a less than average 'gastropub' serving a variety of mediocre offerings. I had the potted shrimp to start, which was ok, albeit a large portion. The other half had the mozzarella which again, was huge, and he said was drowned in mint.Next I has wanted the chicken pie, but that was only for two people, so in the end we both had the pork Milanese. It came with picked red cabbage and pea purée. The cabbage was sickly sweet and was choked with cinnamon, and the pea purée overwhelmed everything. We ordered a side of chips which were dry and tasteless. I asked for a glass of prosecco on arrival, which I had to send back because it was horribly sweet. They didn't have any other variety and wouldn't sell champagne by the glass. We shared a bottle of ribeiro de duero for £36 which was fine.Service was good and prompt. The place filled up quickly as the evening progressed and the atmosphere was good, although they did place all the diners together in the centre of the room. The tables are a bit too close; the back of my chair was touching the back of the next person. Disappointing. I won't return.

tVv9rzfnDZm7ejTdAMy8Pg.text: When have you ever been told that you have to pay for a bottle of wine that was bad? It happened to me at Great Queens Street. Although it was one of my favorite restaurants in London, I'll never go back due to the arrogant and unaccommodating service I received on March 8,  2018. I will try to make this short.I live in New a York City but I am in London often. On that evening, we were a party of five with 7:15 reservations. I ordered a bottle of wine which, when it came, was sour. I asked the waiter (who was lovely throughout) to please replace it since it was sour. He came back and said he could not. I asked to speak to the manager. Someone who said he was a "manager", and who would not give me his name, came and said that the wine was not corked. I told him I knew the wine was not corked; I had said it was sour, not corked.  He told me that it was an organic wine and that that's the way it tasted. I explained that I knew wine and that the wine was not supposed to taste that way. He said it was, and that I was wrong. I ordered different wine which was fine and the evening proceeded nicely. When we received the bill, we were charged for the first sour bottle of wine, along with the additional bottles we ordered, plus a service fee. I went to the "manager" and said that I would pay for either the sour wine, or the service fee, but not both. I also said that since he was so unaccommodating, if I had to pay for the wine, I would never return to the restaurant. I explained that I am a qualified sommelier (absolutely the truth). He nastily responded, "Good luck with that."  He further said that he would prefer if I didn't pay the service fee and never returned. He would not take the sour wine off the bill. I was not offensive, confrontational or abusive. But he was. Awful treatment, awful customer service, awful way to run a business!!!

iT6ajLFlTTXuJ8m4nffMHQ.text: Always have a wonderful meal here! Even my parents insist we eat here every time they visit London (and it's very hard to impress my parents to that level when it comes to food!)Would recommend this to everyone. Got to come and try it out!

541jycVFzlGt9yL4co4HBw.text: We went to Great Queen Street for Sunday lunch.  We were expecting a crowd based on reviews we read, but were surprised to see that plenty of seating was available.  The Sunday lunch menu is limited, but everything available is simple and quite nice.Very, very friendly staff.  The bloody mary was delicious and spicy.  If you're a tourist, please don't foolishly leave because there's no fish and chips!  Stay... you'll be glad you did.

yoxH1QQ9ZZimpHfg5_I0KQ.text: All these reviews made me feel I'd be missing out so Friday night was the perfect time to try this restaurant. It's on a street full of tourist type restaurants and I must have walked past it many times as it looks so unassuming. Once inside there's a lovely casual vibe and despite it being a busy Friday night we weren't rushed along at all. The staff were polite and friendly and it just had a really great, people out with their friends having a nice dinner kind of vibe. We tried the beef for two which was fine, but I think I need to remember beef != steak as it wasn't quite what I was expecting. The menu was full of gorgeous sounding stuff that I can't wait to try though. I'd recommend the roast veal as a starter. Will definitely return.

v5CXppwApu9GFUHr8tR__w.text: This is the sister restaurant to the Anchor & Hope on The Cut, and home to traditional British cooking  gamey, heavy, and tastes like what is on your place was jogging along the hillside just hours before  it probably was. Great for relaxed Sunday lunches or chilled out dinners with friends  superb British cooking with pates, soups and terrines to start, and fresh fish or meat as a main. At the Anchor & Hope version we shared pheasant and rabbit; at 32 Great Queen Street I had tasty pig's cheeks and El G had lamb's neck which looked like it had been guillotined off there and then. Some of our friends ordered the beef rib between six and got half a cow on a plate, cooked to perfection, a slab of rare beef with blood swimming round it. The boys were drooling a la Homer Simpson and someone mentioned the meat sweats  the sort of food I'd imagine served in a country mansion after a hunt years ago. Something your dad or boyfriend would love, and they were super nice to my veggie friend too.

LSog0cCZD6bSuC1_EQ-_YA.text: I'm embarrassed to admit I just discovered this gem of a restaurant. I'm in the area all the time (actually walk by it often), and have cruised right past this place en route to less delicious meals. The snails and bacon on laver bread was delightful and something that I hope stays on the menu permanently. The ribs shared with two mates (none of us little men) were gorgeous too. The beer selection and wine list were inspired. The Manhattans had at the bar at the end of our meal, excellent. When can I go back? Service was efficient and friendly and upfront.

wzA9IDKpYUzHtPcturThMA.text: Ate here based on the good reviews on YELP and was disappointed.  It was by far the worst place we ate in London, including the kebab place in Hackney.  The staff was nice and helpful but the food was not that good and was very expensive.  This is not the place to go if you are in London looking for good pub food.

ecPgL-sW6AlyCOE7OBiizQ.text: Went on a Tuesday night with my two of my foodie friends. Our reservation wasn't until 9pm but we were starving so we headed downstairs to the bar. DO THIS! The bartender was incredible. We had some good beers and he made several recommendations, checked on the specials for us, and explained every item on the menu. By 9pm a lot of the food choices were gone so I would suggest making a reservation and arriving at an earlier time. Do not think that because you are at a nice place they are not going to feed you well! Abandon all ideas of little plates and be prepared to eat hearty heavy food- rabbit pie, pig's cheek, chicken pot pie, potato soup, lamb shoulder.We had the lamb for two. This neck flank could have fed three easily. It was so tender and juicy. I am a big fan of lamb and this was incredibly tender, fall off the bone, melt in your mouth heaven. Only one can imagine what the 7 hour lamb shoulder tastes like.It is loud, fun,crowded, friendly, dark, young, hip. Not too expensive. Wait staff amazing.

X5s0v71CO3JTeUJCrvvXhg.text: Great, attentive staff combined with a talented kitchen and a believably-authentic British menu. I had the pigeon and snails, a dish I would not have considered elsewhere. It was good!A great way to finish a fantastic visit to London.

KmMXgG80NF_K-oky8I9CRg.text: This was either a Yelp let-down or I am just not that into British food, your pick. Our server was very nice, but while I enjoyed my dessert (buttermilk pudding), the rest of the food was rather mediocre. The third star I am giving it is benefit-of-the-doubt-ish as to my personal tastes. Skip the snails (though the bits of black pudding were good, proving I don't hate all culinary things British) and the pig and pigeon terrine. The gnocchi were interesting, but I didn't like the underlying peas. The mackerel special was okay but full of bones, as is apparently customary with most fish dishes here. Sorry, this all just wasn't quite my cup of tea.

tdG-VEgn9DudWjhLoNoq4A.text: This is a nice mix of traditional and avant-garde dishes. We shared in the rabbit and had a few starters. We also booked a table in advance and although the rest of our party was a few minutes late, they kindly seated us already and gave us water/drinks. There was a limited time that we could reserve our table but they encouraged us to move downstairs for desserts and drinks. Our server downstairs was very welcoming.Overall, the meat dishes were cooked very well. The portions were filling and warming. The ambience is polished and cool. The staff lovely and accommodating. This is one of our solid favourites. We will be returning in the near future.

5OWFRicZXIoJhZETK7tqzQ.text: So this place really surpassed expectations.  I was expecting a quick meal before drinks but it was a feast.  We had an entire lamb shoulder to share between12 people, 2 plates of rib-eyes, quail and numerous sides.  The portions were plentiful, the food was delicious (and perfectly cooked) and it's great for family style eating.  A must visit for big groups if you can get a table.

8mw_2Adbr1nwrYeFANTdKw.text: This has been on my favourites list since I went after it opened, and my only grouch is that they aren't open on a Sunday evening (or weren't last time I looked). So it's really all about me. For those of you who've always room for dessert, here's a tip. If you're eating anywhere else locally, come here for it - you can eat at the bar. The creme caramel (made with marsala) is absolutely the best dessert I have ever tasted; certainly in this town. Service is great (if you're nice to them, they're very nice to you), and you'll almost certainly want to go back asap, as I do. Update 15.1.10 Be careful when ordering the Mallard, currently on their menu - unless your January diet's still in force - it's legless and less substantial than you might think, although accompanied by roasted chestnuts and sprouts, all suffused with the scent of wood smoke. A carafe of Douro sufficed, a glass of beaujolais each to accompany a shared anchovy salad, the perennially delicious marsala crème caramel and buttermilk pudding for my friend, our two-and-a-half course meal came in at £68 inc service. Had our duck kept its legs, this would have been a five-starred meal!

0sajTLwjF8X7j55hEDNiCw.text: This is by far the nicest meal I have ever had. I took my boyfriend for his 30th after it being recommended by a colleague, we had the rib of beef, chips&hollandaise sauce followed by tarte tatin. All amazing.The service was good despite the fact that is was a busy Friday night, we had a relaxed drink in the bar downstairs before eating and this was also comfy. I think the nicest thing about this place was the mix of people in there and the fact that it was amazing good not served in fussy or stuffy surroundingsI'll definately be going again.

sLNfG_VnUu8ANvbehw7ZjQ.text: This is the sister restaurant to one of my favourite tables in London - The Anchor and Hope. Everything is the same in terms of great bourgeois cooking and well chosen and resonably priced wines and beers. Last night which was pretty cold I had a very light beetroot soup with sour cream and dill followed by a superb ox cheek stew with (real) chips followed by a sublime seville orange and almond tart served with a scoop of home made vanilla ice cream ! Outstanding ! The main difference with the Anchor is that you can book and of course the location is better if you work nearby or happen to be a Mason !

1PfqX6Y34ZylWaT9oOkPFQ.text: I was in London on business, and this place reminded me of the best of Russian Hill bistros in San Francisco: the food was local and fresh, the chef paid brilliant attention to flavor, and like a true "slow food" exemplar the menu celebrated and refreshed core British traditions.Go, and bring at least two friends, so you can share the wonderfulness!

AWERlvw8jAIuphTHEcCv1A.text: fabulous food.  the specials were exceptional.  we had the braised short ribs which, we were told, had been cooked on low heat for over 12 hours. 12 hours!  the beet and watercress salad was excellent, as well.  all in all, bravo to the chefs at this gastropub!!

xN0QCEw3rjE_aNC0cr69HQ.text: The kind of place that anybody, no matter where you call home, would kill to call their "neighborhood restaurant". If I lived nearby, perhaps in a pod located deep within the bowels of the aforementioned masonic lodge, I could see myself visiting once every week or two. The term "full mouth orgasm" was used.Crowd was eclectic, bordering on the bizarre. A Twin Peaks style collection of hipsters, blue haired theater goers, some post-hip young adults and a few shady Mason types. Decor is nothing to write home about, but it does make for a cozy shack in which to gorge oneself on all the delicious. The food was a full step above your average gastropub fare. -A simple preparation of fresh cockles, sweet and small, bathing in a broth of onion, butter, and an alcoholic beverage I couldn't quite place (almost tasted like madeira, but it definitely wasn't). -Fresh Maldon oysters. Honestly, the liquer was a bit on the muddy side...not really Great Queen's Street fault. I'm just more used to pacific oysters which pander a bit more to my tastes. -The smoked haddock gratin (can't remember their terminology) was a monument to excess, a mound of smoky, creamy savory goodness. - A masterful mushroom ragu over something described as "gnocchi" but what came out appearing as a giant polenta cake. No complaints. This was the best dish of the night. If you've ever heard a chef talk about "building flavors", you'll know what I mean when I say that the sauce was impeccably constructed. It hit every level on the spectrum you would want out of this kind of sauce. Musty, rich, and full. -Scottish Onglet with what appeared to be fresh creamed horseradish, served admirably rare. -For dessert, make sure to get the muscat creme caramel. Sure, it's basically a flan. If flan had a sexier, more delicious cousin. Trust me. Get the damn muscat creme caramel.

LfhAHBLyaX74olYcNR8TPA.text: This is my favorite place to eat in London. I'm not even a fan of British food, but this place makes the earth move for me....Although the decor is nothing fancy, the food is spectacular.  Fresh, Local and very imaginative menus are basically all very delicious.   And the service is fantastic.   The only problem is that the bathroom is down a very steep set of stairs with no handrail.  I try not to use it as I'm afraid I'm going to break my neck.And if you're at the restaurant during the business day, take a walk across the street and visit the Mason's Grand Temple.  Most of the museum is available to non-Masonics and you can see a very comprehensive and different take on world history if you walk through the place.

d0iBw0E-UeFR99wx_qpl7A.text: Going have to bump this to a 5 star as I went here one last time before leaving London. Wait staff was great as always, food divine, and good company. Will always remember this place.

YbvHsRpVz7pFgly2SqHflQ.text: It's a real pleasure to tell you how great this place is. They have a large rectangular ground floor room with earthy red walls and kind lighting. They have resisted the temptation to pack too many tables in and consequently the waiting staff can move freely and the room is alive without being oppressively loud.The staff are excellent for one simple reason: they care. They're interested in the food, the wine, that you're happy with your choice. They want you to enjoy it. This attitude isn't easy to find in London and it really stands out.The menu is an interesting mix of (dreadful word) rustic offerings made with high quality ingredients. The wine list is reasonable and the staff can competently guide you through it. The service is friendly, relaxed and there is no pressure to clear the table.I loved it.

kY5H2OpmwmStYV0r6n-ySw.text: Super friendly staff slipped me onto last spot on bar... place was packed.Had BRILLIANT braised leg of Hare... amazingly good. Were out of apple tart, guy behind the bar suggested a yougurtized pudding w/ raspberries... I would have never picked it myself but it was incredibly delicious.  Nits... would be great to get carrots with the hare :)Place is packed and very loud.  But I expect a great place to be busy.  I had a great experience and great meal... definitely going back.

vXrU2TsmvNG6QFb3_x1TuQ.text: Who says there isn't great food in London? That's just ridiculous, and here's 32 Great Queen Street to prove it!Take what you think as traditional English food fare, strip away mediocrity, too much of any particular ingredient, heavy grease, and all that you'd stereotype as what you wouldn't like about traditional English food, then add a HUGE heaping of fresh and local ingredients, a massive dollop of culinary excellence, healthy helpings, and casual hospitality that defines what going out to dine should be about. Beauty and simplicity all rolled into one.Oh, did I mention that it's pub-casual? Yeah, no white table cloths or cloth napkins. You're getting a fantastic top-shelf food experience without the stuff trappings of fancy restaurants. Feel free to go with a group of your best mates and chat it up without fear that you'd draw any stares. It's perfect spot to share a good time for all.Definitely ring in a few days in advance (if not a week or two) to book a table--especially if you plan on going during peak hours. It's thoroughly worth the trouble.

3ypPykE4TVtHMMgdQWUQGA.text: We went to Great Queen Street today for Sunday lunch.  I had soup to start and then the Lemon Sole.  The food was absolutely outstanding with simple ingredients but rich flavor.  I was surprised that we were the only people there as I've read that people have had a hard time getting in.  I guess I recommend going on a Sunday afternoon...The menu is small which I think it GREAT and everything on it looked fantastic.  Fresh bread kept us happy until our starters came out.  My husband had the Barnsley Chop and he also loved his meal.  Bottom line:  In a rather touristy area,  this is a gem of a gastropub and I highly recommend.

OmARUCsL7KC1fQAGF0OadA.text: Perfect. British food can be excellent but it's super hard to find. This place is so perfect. I shared the chicken pie for 2 with a friend on Wednesday. It's the perfect crust topped with suet. So good I went back with a work mate the next night to share the crispy whole suckling duck. The menu changes a lot and the best stuff is always to be shared by 2 or 3. Additionally, they always have a true craft cask of beer in hand. It actually sits on the bar. Super casual...and comfortable at the bar.

6NkYt19125VFAYDDIKUZ_w.text: I am going back - there were so many other foods on the menu that caught my eye but I just couldn't order all of them.The wine selection is OK - most of them were French therefore dry and not exactly to my taste. But waiter suggested going for sweeter Italian and that's what my friend and I did. And it scored.I like the fact that even though it didn't have availability for Saturday night, the place accommodated us at a bar - and I love bar seating. Honestly I think there should be more restaurants with bar tables only in London.I ordered pork and clams - and I'm not a fan of salt so someone who's keen on that - might not enjoy it, but I liked it - it was warm and hearty - for the cold winds outside.My friend went for the Onglet, and even though it's apparatenly a diaphragm - it tasted like prime fillet steak. But better. I would certainly go back just to have a whole plate of it to myself.There are not 'stir-fry', 'curries' - the menu was British - at least as I can imagine British cuisine like to be when there were no KFC and McDonalds.It's a bit shabby - I didn't like the table arrangements and the lighting - well it's just a dark place, I think with some refurbushiment they could easily score a 5.I would certainly try the smoked roe and some of their desserts next time I'm there!

xv_nzBGs4qh-wP1D2NF8uA.text: A very nice place for dinner. It is on the pricier side with some unique foods. We just ordered a ton of appetizers since the main courses did not look too interesting. Apps are great. We did also have a steak pie. The crust was amazing!

z7z4Ncgp3uCMWaj_3CsUBQ.text: Hmmmm....a little underwhelmed with my meal but enjoyed the direction and feel of the food.Started with the smoked roe, cucumber, radish, and baby gem lettuce salad. This dish was quite tasty, but I had a minor gripe; the smoked roe stuck together so you would have large bitter bites of roe in and out of your dish. Near the end this sort of killed me palate. Overall quite nice though...Next, I had one of the daily specials..a whole artichoke. This was a huge let down. I could tell that the quality of the artichoke was high, but it was so bland to the point of dismissing the dish entirely. Furthermore, it was served with a mustardy sauce that was way too bitter and not savory at all. The mixture of bland and overpowering was a major let down.Finally, I had another special: fried rabbit shoulder and celeraic remoulade. Quite hit or miss as well. I feel that although the quality of the rabbit was exceptional, the fried aspect of it overloaded the taste. The rabbit was already gamy and a bit fatty...frying the cut was a bit too much. That being said, the taste was nice and reminded me of Southern chicken. The celeraic remoulade made me sad face as well. It was a tad bit too bitter and empty as far as ingredients go. I wish it went somewhere.I'd give this place 3.5 stars if possible due to the quality of the ingredients and interesting combinations, but I don't think the execution is on the same level as it would appear when reading the menu.

LQJmJuX9vF5_hFIedwQkeA.text: Absolutely wonderful experience here. The food is inventive and adventuresome. The service smooth and attentive. Coming back before we leave London.

SR5WS3KTxvYD5D_fSMY7iA.text: Went for lunch, ordering the quail, a Syrah, and chips.  All my food was excellent and delicious.  The Syrah was wine (not a connoisseur!), which is what I asked of it.  Very good food, and the prices seem reasonable to me.

jLkJbYs72dViUoBTxRKqVg.text: Phenomenal!  Came in because of the Yelp reviews and they didn't disappoint. Fantastic service, the oysters were perfect, had the beef and chorizo; wife had the something weird with an egg on it but it was also delicious.

JORa_FfFwOTTeh76IeQT4w.text: Been three times for dinner and had fantastic experiences each time. Great ambience, comfortable service, and top-notch food that's just a tiny bit different than what you'd get somewhere else. Great for a pre-theatre meal, or for a date.

Vg-vS3Ake0K2ZY7GydloMg.text: It is odd for me to walk into a restaurant and be totally stuck on what to eat. It wasn't because I was being indecisive, it was because, apart from the potato soup that was delicious and the shrimp, I had no taste experience of anything else on the list. Great Queen Street serves impressive British cuisine with offerings such as pigeon, sole and other non typical delights. Your usual eating habits may have to take a detour, as there wasn't a burger or a plate of chips in sight.All the dishes brought to the table looked excellent. My pigeon looked like a little chicken, but once you cut into it, the flesh looks and tastes like beef. Yet it went exceptionally well with the fois gras and lentils. I had to order potatoes as a side dish. They were good to. All in all, Great Queen Street is a pretty expensive casual British restaurant, serving from a high end menu that smacks of the upper class. I was there for lunch and had a good experience, but wish I got to try one of the lovely sounding desserts. The starters and mains although very good, aren't quite my style. One needs quite a refined palate to fully appreciate this place to its fullest.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

eKGnhMp4R6D3CKqUenNjgQ.text: Thank the Maker! At last, a meal worth eating, if a little on the pricey side. Excellent eats and beautiful service at Great Queen Street. I ordered a heritage sirloin special and herb salad. Steak flavorful and well-cooked; salad interesting, not overdressed. Server was kind enough to offer chocolate sorbet for pudding. From first to last, an excellent experience. Quality food, not fussy. Warm atmosphere. Recommended.

TlboM8FFr0cK3setRhFrNw.text: Have only been to the cellar bar, but this place is a hidden gem! Nice selection of wine, and delicious cheese plate of local cheese, right from Neale's Yard! Alex the friendly bartender plays a nice eclectic mix of music from the 60's and 70's. Restaurant is always buzzing - I'll definitely check it out soon.

jf0AGcHuChwmEd_FZ-sTBg.text: Great Queen Street this restaurant was very busy and has a lot of good reviews within this app, hence giving it a try.  I just think it is a bit outrageous when they want to charge you 12.5% service charge for bringing your food to you, when that's what we all get paid to do a job!  I was about to leave a tip (having asked for the automatic 12-5% to be removed off the bill) when the manager came over asking why? I think this is the bit outrageous.  Personally the menu wasn't exactly what I'd choose so I had a vegetarian dish which average price was £14 with no sides so side orders of chips potatoes £4 vegetables £4. I would not be returning to this place.

w41CSKwGseZJ3AcSfXbxBA.text: Our incredibly knowledgeable server had a fact-filled and eloquent answer for each and every one of our many questions. I love when I leave a restaurant feeling like I've received something of an epicurean education whilst inside.Not one to turn down cauliflower in any form, I opted to start with the cauliflower soup. Luscious and satisfying, I couldn't imagine a better appetizer.After hearing the description of the rabbit pie on special I knew I had to have it. Thankfully, my dining companions were up for taking it on together.Great Queen Street gave me a distinct appreciation for suet crust pastry. Before eating their incredible rabbit pie, I didn't have a clue about suet or the magical deliciousness it can impart. Additionally, I was completely ignorant to the fact that rabbit, when slow cooked, ends up tasting a lot like chicken without a hint of gaminess. Great Queen Street provided me with a level of satiation that's been tough to find elsewhere in London; I'm already looking forward to my next visit.

DEACKv-eHkw1UniymhbD-g.text: Traditional English food in a relaxed setting. The menu changes daily - however you can expect a few gamey meat options most the time. If they have a Beef Wellington on menu that day, get it!

hQ2sFEoo1pnroSBexslLSw.text: A gastro-pub in the land of pubs.  This is a great place and a great way to start your time in London.  The place was packed, with a good vibe and upbeat crowd so a reservation is absolutely required.The menu is seasonal and so it will change.  On this visit, we (2 of us) had the following:  Starters:Snail salad -- this was a special of the day.  Snails served warm with bacon and lettuce.  It was delicious.Cuttlefish -- a member of the same family as octopus and squid, this dish is served with the cuttlefish being cubed and served with peas and wild garlic.  At first, I was not happy with the dish, but with each bite, it seemed to grow on me.  I would probably pass and try something else, but it still was enjoyable.  Main:Rib of Hereford beef -- this is a dish that is meant to be shared by two people and takes 45 minutes.  It was worth the wait.  The beef was perfectly cooked rare and served with a side of Bearnaise sauce.  Also accompanying the dish was a bowl of french fries (chips) that were perfectly crispy on the outside and meaty on the inside.Dessert:Apple treacle tart.  An apple pie of sorts that has a crunchy crust and nice crunchy top, with a sweet interior.  This is a perfect dessert to end the evening.

_SjXFto_EpO71e0sNEhSbA.text: As an American I was definitely satisfied with the British-ness of the menu which included duck giblets and roast pigeon.  In the end I wussed out and had the sole with whelk butter.  Even then the fish arrived whole with all the bones in, and so was pleasingly non-American in both look and taste.  Also it was really, really good.  Especially the garlic in the whelk butter was unbelievably flavorful.I was alone so I ate at the bar which was a little cramped.  But the staff were friendly and the service was prompt even though it was Saturday night and the place was packed.

kix4AMb7yAXJhYsG8GvIhA.text: Just far enough out of the heart of Covent Garden to have a bustle without being too crowded.  Exactly what I was looking for  - a place that was as concerned with the food as with the drink.  Every bite was delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Cured mackerel and pickled cucumber with cream cheese mousse.
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp, broccoli, leeks and anchovy dressing.
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Lamb sweetbreads, "mushy" peas and mint sauce.

b6RZkFCauJD2pigsDlpKnA.text: Was so impressed by this place! Had pig's cheek with an apple sauce and braised cider and it was exquisite.The wait staff were all very kind and helpful - our waiter gave us a copy of the menu and wrote out the specials for us including the prices. After conversing with him for a bit, he suggested other British restaurants for us to try.Great atmosphere and experience overall! Only criticism I have is the closeness of the tables - it was hard to get out of my chair as I was leaving.

Lkj2nnzhK1QfTLMYY6z7yg.text: This is my favorite gastropub in London. When people ask me for a recommendation for "British food but I don't to just eat fish and chips or anything bland", I send them here. I took a friend from out of town here during the winter and we had a really delicious, relaxed meal at the bar with some strong drinks that were surprisingly reasonably-priced, for the location. Food was well-made and portions were deceptively large! Seems like they rotate the menu regularly as well to use in-season ingredients. I had a salad with rabbit and bacon and some other things in it a while back, and it was literally the best salad I've ever eaten, and I'm sad that I haven't seen it again on the menu since. GREAT QUEEN STREET IF YOU'RE READING THIS PLEASE BRING IT BACK!It's not the cheapest place, but for the quality and creativity of the dishes prepared here, it's well worth the price! For anything else within a stone's throw of the British Museum, GQS is hard to beat.They take group bookings and it's really nice that they don't force your whole group to order off a prix fixe menu the way that it seems lots of gastropubs these days do.

djsF9oHikfY4YvmA-kAG8w.text: First of all.. Thank you Yelp, without you guys I wouldn't have found this restaurant. Jetlagged and hungry but not wanting a big meal, the team at Great Queen Street recommended the salad of Heritage Tomatoes, Peach, Yogurt and Cumin salt followed by the griddled French quail and chenterelle butter. Cumin salt brought out the full sweetness of the Tomatoes and Peach. Now on to the best part.THIS IS THE BEST QUAIL I've ever had! Nicely crispy grilled on the outside yet juicy and full of flavor on the inside. Chenterelle mushrooms was fragrant added with the butter gravy had the right amount of salt without being overly salty nor oily. A pity that the meal had to come to an end. I want more!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom

0OD-_Rj6vxDJihlCzG5nvg.text: Holy crappoli. We were cold as hell and wandering through London as my phone died. We needed food, but a lot of places were closed. We remembered that Great Queen Street was nearby, and had read good things on Yelp! It was our last night, so we decided to treat ourselves.First of all, the place is pricey. It isn't CRAZY pricey, but I wouldn't call it a "value" joint. The restaurant itself is very packed, but with enough room for everyone - I would say "efficient" seating. No wasted space. We got in, and ordered a couple of the specials - they were very good. The greens and pie were amazing. I would give it 5 stars. The service (even by UK standards) was not good. We were STARVING and didn't get our bread/drinks until we asked for it several times. It was busy, but people seated after us had received theirs long before us.  So, 3 stars for service.  Overall, a really big fan of the place and a solid four stars!!  Will be back the next time we hop over the pond.

HOhV8VmLmB2bnX948mj1Zw.text: We had an excellent meal sharing several of the dishes including the quail and lemon sole. Our kids who were exhausted and cranky from a day of sightseeing and walking even came around and enjoyed it as well. We did not have a reservation but were seated immediately around 6:30 pm. The desserts were very good as well. The service was great and very informative about the dishes. An excellent experience overall on our visit to London.

nQY4tK5SPQhP7ovH9o6UTA.text: The grilled squid was cooked to just the right tenderness, the lamb kidneys were perfectly and delicately spiced with cumin and red pepper while the roasted eggplant laced with soft roasted garlic, and the chocolate fritters were a  revelation. Plus thoughtful service. As good as British food gets.

mGYxYCk7cMXs-JSAnLdA3A.text: Traditional British food and service at this bustling restaurant on Great Queen Street. I enjoyed the warm duck salad and lamb's kidneys. Attentive service, reasonably priced and good atmosphere. Minor observation, tables are a little bit on the small side.

OV36uDOqOOQRSoudPNifWA.text: I came here having visited their sister restaurant Anchor & Hope, which I loved. I ended up going for the Workers Lunch menu which is a set two course for £18. I started with a main which was homemade sausages mixed in house. It was lovely, flavoursome but it was so small and had no substance to the dish. I then went with what was supposed to be a selection of cheeses from Neal's Yard and all I got was one cheese with a few Oaty biscuits. Overall I was underwhelmed by the size and generosity of the dishes and do not believe it deserved to warrant the higher lunch price. (Visit - 03/07/2015 Lunch)

fudujpsBsj3qtUXCSFCxmg.text: I came here upon the back of many great reviews, and I have to say that I'm impressed.I am not particular fan of British food, and my quest for good British food has been met with plenty of disappointing meals that never hit me in quite the right way. I've been here for 4 months already, and for some reason I've always made it a point to try something British at least once a week. If you do the math, that's over 15 places already - and still nothing that I really enjoyed.Until now.Not only did the waitress know the menu fully in-and-out, she was able to describe why she liked a particular dish - how long each dish had been in rotation, and what the chef was trying to accomplish with the ingredients. I am not sure how she manages to remember this for a rotating menu, but I decided to go for the newest item - the grouse pasta.The grouse was slow cooked and pulled apart, very tender and juicy without losing its gaminess. The vegetables that accompanied the grouse in a sort of stew-like fashion paired perfectly. The pasta was ziti and soaked up the stew very well. Overall a great meal, and one that's going to have me returning for quite a while.

7wG0hNuiDck2CLSHHVunaA.text: Definitely bang on every buck!  Who said the Brits don't have good food?!?!?  I loved the meal, fresh ingredients, delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Pork chop was so delicious!  N
Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Cheese was divine

_BjZljqUUhDtb8WvnvntyQ.text: We were out sightseeing our first day in London, and- although Westminster Abbey was closed, got there just as the 5 PM service with chorus was just being seated.  Great experience #1 of the evening.  When we got out, we realized we hadn't eaten all day, saw this place on Yelp and grabbed a quick cab.  We didn't have reservations, but were seated at 6:15 PM at a table that was reserved for another party - but not until 8:00 PM. Great experience #2!1 hr. and 45 minutes later, after pigs cheek and duck terrine, snails (did someone say they didn't like the snails???) and a rabbit and chestnut mushroom pie with a side of greens - oh-  and a plum and almond tart we split with cappuccino, we left and walked around all evening.  Best meal of the trip, for certain. Wait staff was amazing, as was the owner/manager.

kzaCA2Cuwzadmll8kj-f9g.text: Was looking for a place to have a last dinner before heading back to the states, and I couldn't have asked for a better place to end my experience in London. Even though the restaurant was packed, the food and service was excellent and absolutely delicious; which is probably why they were so busy. As far as price, this place was on point. When I got the ticket, I was surprised by how much the ticket was. However so, remember that the service charge isn't included, so it wouldn't hurt to leave a little extra! Especially due to the seriously outstanding service you may receive here.

G5OfXqjUvsvW-5LmifM6HQ.text: If you like high end English food, this is a great place.  I recently had lunch here on vacation.  I started with a pork terrine and followed it up with a roasted partridge.   Both dishes were excellent.  I would give it five stars for the dishes I had, but I have to warn you that picky eaters might have some issues with the menu.  It's a little more gourmand than a pub.   Also the tables and chairs are small and you are sort of packed in there.

RF2uwLM3DfUnTUKxZMcyQw.text: This may be my favorite gastropub in London, after having visited about three times. If you can, get a seat near the window so you can watch people pass by. I have an English friend who now lives abroad, and she always mentions this place when we're in central London and looking for a place to eat. Now we bring our other friends here when they come to visit.During my second visit, I've enjoyed a whole fish for two, covered in vegetables and delicious sauce. On the most recent visit, I saw duck on the menu and couldn't say no. They paired it will an onion chutney and parsnips. Every duck loves a sweet accompaniment. Gluten-free notes: Most dishes here are naturally gluten free, and they were happy to advise about what was OK and what wasn't.

xDDL9f-fhEl-gqVv11l4ww.text: While in London, I was in the search for tasty, affordable, and authentic British cuisine. I've heard my fair shares of how "British food is horrible!" and "You're going to lose so much weight when you come back from the UK because you won't eat anything" yadda yadda - Not so, my friends. Not only is Great Queen Street restaurant's menu full of game and all your traditional British-y foods, the food was mind you very delicious. Honestly, without a smart phone, I don't know how anyone coming here can order without looking up half the stuff on the menu. Because it has been more than a few weeks since I checked in here, I can't recite the names of the dishes off my head but they were very complicated and you'll find yourself asking the staff what exactly you are reading and is the menu still in English. Luckily, the waitress was super helpful and knowledgeable and was able to tell me exactly what was what. I played it safe anyways and got something I could pronounce - the partridge. It was my first time having partridge so I can't compare but it was pretty tasty if not plain messy. Don't think you're going to get through this entire bird without using your hands. I was hoping no one would see what a noob I was at eating whole gamey birds, but boy I was glad my waitress was attentive enough to see me struggle cause she brought over a dish of water so I could dig in and get real dirty eating. On a lunch day, I think you could score a seat without reservations but I can see how this big restaurant can easily fill up with people at night. It's good for both groups and small parties because they have the space and the table sizes of all kind. To sum it up, have your smartphone with you to look up food on the menu, attentive staff, prepared to get hands dirty if you order partridge.

photos.caption: Photo of Great Queen Street - London, United Kingdom. Partridge

8iNlXvjXw8c8J0RLglCSHQ.text: Don't be put off by the tables and lack of fancy signage outside the front of the pub (which look like a mid-tier cafe). I walked inside and had a great lunch. Make sure you ask the staff for recommendations - they helped me pick the food (I had slow cooked pork) and guest ale (excellent one from Hampshire) and even advised me not to order sides dishes, as they would be unnecessary unless I was starving. Even recommended other (competing) pubs. Great, lively pub/ restaurant atmosphere and food, with genuinely helpful staff. I'll be back

MOEiBP6vgeoC_DU7F7UZLg.text: Cozy place, good for a catch up with an old friend or a small group dinner. Starters were so-so: smoked aubergine/ricotta/tomato and cockles...with stuff...Roast chicken wasn't bad (tad dry) but the greens it came with were heavenly.  Dessert was tasty too: coffee honeycomb ice cream and a biscuit and some kind of tart (which my dinner mate ate completely so I have no idea what it tasted like).Homemade lemonade was perfect on a hot evening too!

RJ1AX7w5x-5hOJyIWNjqXA.text: Excellent service, delicious steak pie, super close to the theatre district.

Vj1MycfAeJ264Qmr2S5wtg.text: We are foodies! We asked the Concierge for a non tourist restaurant (as we always do when traveling). He suggested Anchor & Hope. The restaurant magnanimouslyaccepted our last minute reservation under the condition that we be OUT in one hour. That was fine with us. We jumped in a cab & arrived 25 minuted early. The restaurant was mostly empty. We reminded the MAÎTRE D'/waiter that our reservation was not for another 25 minutes, but we were early and wanted to respect their request to be OUT within one hour. Our arrival time gave us an extra 1/2 cushion.One would think that they would promptly serve us. NO. It took almost 20 minutes for them to ASK what we wanted to drink. 10 minutes to take our food order at which time THEY realized the time and were now rushing US.  We ordered lamb (wanting to eat one of their specialties.) They said that all the food is made to order and that the Chef ONLY cooks HIS way, and that we could not have it medium rare. OK fine. CAN YOU SAY RUBBER/GRIZZLE? We cut away so much that was inedible, all that was left were mouse scraps. The waiter also pushed a side salad (and I use the term loosely). It was an over filled, under sized bowl of straight "out of the bag" spring greens. We didn't even bother eating it. We left HUNGRY! We had better food anywhere else in London. All they accomplished was to perpetuate England's OLD reputation of having terrible food!I asked about the Free Mason Lodge across the street, (seeing men in black coming out with the same square briefcases). It was one of the few times the waiter actually smiled, he said "They don't come here anymore because they don't like the way we treat them"!You're not alone boys!There was NOTHING redeeming about this restaurant. Let's assume that they thought we would not be repeat customers and gave us pathetic food. Wake up Anchor & Hope! It's a small world out there and the internet is VERY BIG! People, don't waste your time. We would have been better off in a fast food joint!

-jjM-6sWIxCJczlzf0QqhA.text: Excellent "gastro-bistro" near Holborn tube station. The menu has something for everyone but emphasizes hearty dishes - game, meat pies, etc.  They won't like me saying this, but the "seven hour lamb for three" (braised lamb shoulder with root veg and very rich pommes dauphinois) will feed four people easily. They are into bold flavors here, letting the food speak for itself amid a relaxed vibe and simple surroundings that recall a country pub with a serious cook rather than a Central London bistro .  Thoughtful and varying selection of wines and beers.  Prices quite reasonable considering the location and the quality on the plate.  It's a standby for me whenever I'm in London.
